I remember when [b]Invisible Inc.[/b] released 8 years ago, but never bothered to purchase even though it was a game that appealed to me.  After finally picking it up on Steam Sale this past summer, I can positively say this is one of Klei Entertainment’s most critically underrated titles deserving of more attention.  

Thematically, it’s basically a heist game where your group of agents have to infiltrate rival corporate locations for intel, money, equipment, programs and extra personnel.  You need to strategize every engagement because of the constantly increasing alarm levels which add new layers of stress for your escape, such as more [i](armored)[/i] guards, cameras, drones, daemon programs and additional mission objectives.  All of which work in tandem for a variety of challenging playthroughs.  

What really makes Invisible Inc. stand above the rest is how the game is brilliantly crafted to force every decision as a balance between risk & reward.  Do you knock out a guard, only to have him wake up several turns later and actively hunt for you?  Do you continue exploring the level for more safes, even after completing mission objectives and finding the exit?  Is there enough time left for your escape before heavy reinforcements arrive?  Is it worth buying items/augments, or better to save that money for special A.I. programs?  The difficulty begins to shine when you start realizing your choices have consequences.  Unfortunately, there is a “rewind” system available so you can spam your way through every level, if you so desire.  This handicap aside, Invisible Inc. is refreshingly engaging for anyone looking to expand their library of stealth strategy games.  It’s fun, intense and smart, with good voice acting, cool music and stylized artwork befitting the genre. 

Beyond the base game and DLC expansion –[b]Contingency Plan[/b]–  there are a number of great mods designed to supplement Invisible Inc.’s variety of gameplay options and extend its replay value.  You can fine tune the exact number of days before your final mission, adjust the quantity of guards per level, alter how much money you can loot from safes, define the number of rooms per mission, etc.  There are even community made agents, loading screens, A.I. programs / daemons, mission objectives, item & augment rebalances, plus quality-of-life updates.

Great game. It's similar to XCOM in some ways, but other aspects are different like a greater focus on stealth and not having the need (or the ability) to kill every enemy or secure the AO. Even the story-critical missions are procedurally generated and quite different from run to run. The customization options are immense, too.

Another particular strong point is the music. While the number of discrete tracks is fairly small, they're incredibly dynamic and can change in almost a dozen ways based on the enemy's alarm level, the status of the objective, the view you're in, etc. Aside from games like Crypt of the Necrodancer where the music is itself part of the gameplay, I've never played another game that integrates it so well into the experience.

And because it's Klei, you know the game is so well optimized and lightweight that it'll practically run on a potato.

There are a couple minor flaws, namely that a small number of agents and programs are underpowered and that there are quite a few typos and grammatical errors in the text. But the former can be taken as an extra challenge or modded, and the latter has no impact on the gameplay (and presumably could also be modded).

Highly recommended for turn-based tactical fans and anyone looking to get into the genre.

[hr][/hr]

[b]Invisible Inc.[/b] is maybe the greatest mix of stealth and turn based strategy I’ve seen in a game as of yet, and it achieves by making everything understandable at a glance without ever being too complex to make you feel cheated by it.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Let’s start with the base mechanics of the game:
You control multiple characters who move on a square grid (but still capable of diagonal movement).
The map has no elevation nor terrain-based hazards so it simplifies movement into movable squares or not.
Weapons and items are straightforward such as “stun a guard for 3 turns” or “turn invisible until the start of your next turn”.
The game won’t have you guessing, there’s no randomness besides the map generation, no percentage to miss or to be seen or not by a guard, it always communicates to you what’s going to happen, while still relying on your common sense to not run into an unexplored room.

As for stealth:
Enemies have two cones of vision, a narrow one where you’ll be noticed and held at gunpoint on the spot, and a peripheral one where they’ll see movement and investigate it once it’s their turn, furthermore many environmental objects such as desks, crates, safes and more can be used for concealment, couple that with the ability to peek through doors, around corners and to predict the enemy patrol path and you’ll be able to move through crowded rooms like a shadow.

Combat is optional, and you’ll have many tools to stay out of trouble, from hacking enemy drones to scout ahead to using decoy and teleporters to get around a problem.

And to conclude the gameplay overview, it sometimes plays like a roguelike, you’ll have 72 hours to complete as many missions as you can before the final one, get all of your agents killed and it’s back to square one, but with some new unlocks.

[h1]Story[/h1]
Nothing to write home about but it serves its purpose, someone sniffed you out and raided your base, you were able to escape but now your AI is on life support, and without it you’ll be crushed immediately, this way placing you in the shoes of an elite group of spies for the most advanced espionage company in the world, you’ll have to find a way to get your AI on its feet while collecting info about who commissioned the raid.

[h1]X-Factor[/h1]
As for graphics, it’s the classic Kilei style, very cartoony but also very well animated, and music follows suit.

[h1]Downsides[/h1]
The game plays a very cruel way, it makes extremely easy for you to savescum and it goes as far as being built into the game’s mechanics, but if you want to challenge yourself and not do it the game will just as easily take away over 10 hours of progress from your doomed save.
[hr][/hr]

It’s a great game even if a bit anxiety inducing, never knowing what awaits you in the next room and even a wrong step could mean your run is over, but still, very recommended.

I like it, but I don't love it. 

Invisible Inc is a rogue-lite turn-based stealth game where you are some cyberpunk operators out to fight some corporations. You do a couple missions in procedurally generated levels with the goal of unlocking additional operators, cybernetics, equipment, and skills in preparation of a final gauntlet. 

I think my biggest problem with Invisible Inc. is that it feels like there's not enough here. This feels like a proof of concept rather than a full release (though I haven't played the Contingency Plan DLC). Every level is essentially the same; you scout with your operator who reveals hackables behind walls, you hack those to reveal the next room, you avoid the guards (who have some of the most pathetic patrols I've seen in a game thanks to the procedurally generated rooms), reach the objective and get out. 

The entire thing plays very slowly. You need to be extremely cautious, so you'll have turns where you walk up to a door, peep through it, and then end your turn because you need the guard to look the other way. It's tiresome and repetitive because this is how you approach every single room in every single level. You can unlock some other abilities, like being able to make sound later on, but the core gameplay is this cycle of approach, peek, wait, move. 

One of the biggest problems I had in my time with Invisible Inc. was not having enough options to buy things. Randomly generated store might appear during a level and then you have an opportunity to buy 1 random item between missions, but I found that either the store literally had nothing in it or the items in the store were so situational that I didn't *want* to buy them because the same currency that could be used for a weapon could instead be used to give my operators more moves per turn. 

There's a lot more I could say about the daemon programs, the alarm system the makes each level progressively more difficult, or how knockouts work... but honestly it's not worth dragging Invisible Inc. through the mud. 

It's a fine experience to waste a few hours and get some unique looking cyberpunk designs, but I don't think this will end up on my list of "comfort" games I play while listening to a podcast or when I have some time between tasks.

135695861.review:
I can't believe that the best tactics game ever was done in 2015 and nobody told me.

Invisible, Inc. is an exceptionally good game (especially for its price point), with no major flaws while punching all the right buttons. It might be the best roguelike I have played. 

It is fundamentally, Metal Gear Solid meets tactical gameplay, and it is a masterful combination of both elements.  It also has a very cool pace where every mission starts slow, as guards don't search for you seriously and the devices you need to hack into are not well secured, but as you get noticed more, and you continue through your objectives, more guards get spawned, everything becomes better guarded, and guards get more aggressive. This makes every mission feel very tense, and with a very unique sense of buildup; missions will usually start with you rapidly scouting for your objective and taking over the facility, and usually it ends with you scrambling to clutch a sprint towards the exit. It is tense from start to finish.

As with most roguelikes, there is a steep learning curve to this game; however, the developers were kind enough to include two "learning" modes for the game: a beginner mode that has a lot of rewinds, level retiries and generally forgiving gameplay, to a more challenging experienced mode where every mechanic that seems inconsequential starts to come together, as you realize that every decision that you make factors into your success or failure. As a roguelike, if you lose, it's game over, so everything counts.

Lastly, as my only major gripe with the game (and in certain way, ironic), is it's absolute cliffhanger of an ending. While the DLC fixes the small issue I had with the campaign being too short (only 3 days long, expanded to 7, giving you more time to take bigger challenges and assemble a stronger team). I am not particularly bothered by the direction, as I don't necessarily want a "good" resolution to my efforts, but I feel extremely cheated out of a proper resolution at all, which just made want more. I just *need* to know what happens after the ending, and since this game is 8 years old at the time of this review, and Klei does not create sequels (unless you count Don't Starve Together I guess), there's close to 0 chance we will ever get a proper resolution for the story.

Which is another noteworthy thing about the game: I know that the bar for roguelike stories are *very* slow, and while it doesn't get super developed (I'd think Othercide is a better example of a fully fledged-out story), the moments that we get and the character interactions that exist make the immerssion into the universe so much deeper, that it just makes me wish that the game resolved its own plot threads.

TL;DR, if you like stealth, tactics, or roguelikes, but this game. You will not be dissappointed.

135059694.review:
One of Klei's older titles that stands the test of time, Invisible Inc. is a stealth game where you're rewarded for avoiding confrontations and thinking outside of the box. You'll take a party of two starting agents (with the ability to recruit up to four) and challenge various missions across the globe, over the course of 72 in-game hours. Every outing takes some time off the clock, and your ultimate goal is to build up your team before tackling the final mission.

Setting this title apart from other stealth games is the addition of Incognita, an Artificial Intelligence capable of hacking corporate mainframes to provide your party with additional benefits during a mission. Not only will you be sneaking around, dodging and subduing guards, and carrying out your objectives; Incognita will also be taking down network devices, sabotaging drones & defenses, and generally making life miserable for the opposition. This is very much a "Man & Machine" collaboration, where both sides must be synchronized if success is to be achieved.

Replay-ability comes about from the procedural generation of maps (ensuring no two maps are the same), the vast array of available agents with their own strengths & weaknesses, the number of Incognita programs available and the plethora of strategies available for tackling a mission. Unlike most games, there is no "one strategy to rule them all", as your time is limited and gaining specific types of gear is not guaranteed. The addition of an "Alarm System" during missions also encourages players to quickly proceed, as opposed to slowly stacking the odds in their favour; you won't be pinning multiple guards with one agent for very long if he's to escape in time. Nor will you be guaranteed the "best gear load-out" for your agents before the game ends.
Further expanding on this, you're provided with a wealth of customization options to tailor the game exactly as you wish. And with extensive workshop support, plus a community that's made a huge amount of supporting content, the possibilities are endless.

If you're a fan of turn-based strategy or stealth games, I highly recommend picking this game up. While underrated, it's a great example of Klei's breadth when it comes to making quality games and really nails the creativity of indie games in general.

A very underrated stealth rouge like game quite unlike almost anything else I've ever played. Then you have a bunch of characters which every time you get you just kick yourself for not getting anything better: rescuing Shalem, Decker or Banks (archived or not) can make your run feel so much worse then getting one of more interesting characters like Dr. Xu, Nika or Sharp. I'm really fond of this game, but I can understand if others find it niche: if you liked into the breach or enjoy tactics, stealth and rouge like games, this game will really speak to you. Otherwise, it's a bit of a chance, but one I think you might find really fun.

PS: This games world design, world building and aesthetics and characters are all great: it saddens me to know this IP will likely be in limbo for all eternity since Klei is mostly working on don't starve these days. One of my dreams would be for this game to get a sequel of some kind or an animated prequel series, as there really is a lot of untapped potential with this IP. But a man can only dream.

It's one of my all-time favourites. A turn-based stealth game with a unique, tense gameplay that will keep you on the edge of your seat. It combines exploration, stealth, short and long-term planning in a procedurally-generated environment that stays fresh and unpredictable even after 50+ hours.

It will take you on an emotional rollercoaster - from initial confidence to total devastation when you make mistakes that end in a disaster, from doubt and despair to exhilaration when you manage to get out of a seemingly hopeless situation. Rarely any game makes me feel this way.

You play as an underdog, not an overpowered superhero like in most games. You have no chance in direct combat, outnumbered and outgunned by guards who become absurdly overpowered later in the game. You're like a mouse in a room full of cats. Your characters are not muscular super soldiers like in XCom but fragile individuals with their stories and personalities (and stylish outfits). The only advantage you have is intel and planning. Game gives you a lot of info and it's up to you to make best use of it. That's one of the reasons why I absolutely love this game.

I think Invisible Inc. is not wildly popular because it's quite difficult (especially for beginners), nerve-wracking (with increasing alarm and the need to constantly analyze) and it's not a shooter like XCom. Tutorial doesn't cover everything, so you'll need to experiment and figure out stuff on your own and you will fail a lot at the beginning.

If you're feeling it's too hard for you, watch [url=https://www.youtube.com/@AndrewKay/playlists] Andrew Kay play [/url] - it will help you bring your game to the next level. And it's a roguelike, so it's meant to be replayed on a higher difficulty, just like chess - you don't quit after one match. 

Every aspect of this game is perfect to me - gameplay, art style, writing, sound & music, voice overs... Mastery of game design. It's smart and stylish and I could play it forever.

If you want to feel sneaky and secret-agent like, and like a bit of turn-based puzzling your way out of difficult situations, you definitely need to check this game out. 

You play a varying team of infiltrating agents who are teleported onto the floor of an enemy building and have to sneak around guards, drones, security cameras etc., to steal stuff, free prisoners, etc., The setting is futuristic (2074), where a cold-war spy feeling meets cyberpunk and polished, stylish graphics. There's lot of difficult decisions to make, tension and suspense, but at the same time the game maintains a very enjoyable lightheartedness, both in content (a bit of dry humor here and there, the way the characters dash about, the snarky comments and fun enemy exclamations, ...) and in gameplay experience (you're not really heavily punished if you fail missions and campaigns but you simply fail and move on; the preference for sneaking around instead of attacking, ...), which makes this game such a perfect companion to spend from 20 minutes to several hours with.

Although you can KO guards and even kill them, the idea is that those are secondary options and you try to remain hidden and supersneaky. There's lots of gadgets and upgrades to explore and to help you both in being sneaky, and in attacking when necessary. Enemies are varied in strength and capabilities and how they look, there's humans, drones, daemons, ..., all very fun and cool. Nice little background story with a few twists. The whole thing is just very enjoyable and very, very replayable. Floor layouts are procedurally generated so it's always a new challenge. They are also always neither too easy nor too difficult, so the procedural generation is really top notch. And there are endless combinations of characters, gadgets and upgrades, and even play styles. Graphics are crisp and stylish (while extremely light on GPU requirements), user interface feels smooth, it all fits perfectly. 
I suspect this will be a game I will be coming back to a lot for a very long time.

129823593.review:
[h1] A Fun Challenge, Worth the Price [/h1]


Overall, Invisible INC is a well-polished indie title, with intricate gameplay mechanics, fast-paced menus, short load times, quality music that adapts to your circumstances in the level, great visuals, decent voice-acting. At twenty hours in, I feel like the $1/hour price tag has been well worth it.

I would imagine a lot of the negative reviews came from players whose strategies weren't working out, and they blamed the game for being "poorly-designed" rather than changing their tactics. Like many rouge-likes, this game doesn't hold your hand, the tutorial was very minimal, the only way to understand effective strategies is try them out and adapt your approach based on your failures. There is also some game knowledge required to build an effective run (I'm reminded of the flagship fight in FTL--you're not expected to beat it the first time you reach it; it's [i] supposed [/i] to feel overwhelming). I found that process of discovery and adaptation very rewarding. My heart rate went through the roof the first time I played the final mission.

For what it's worth, there is a built-in "save-scum" feature (basically an "undo your last turn" feature) that has limited uses per run, and the number of uses decreases as you increase the difficulty. Some might scoff at this, but I actually appreciated it and felt like it was a fair inclusion. It really helps speed up the learning process. On the beginning difficulty settings, if you try something that doesn't work and your agents die, you can just restart the [i] turn[/i], rather than having to restart the entire playthrough.

This game feels hugely underrated. The engine and game play mechanics have so much potential, I wish more developers would integrate Invisible Inc.'s stealth concepts into their games. Fans of turn-based strategy and rouge-likes should both be able to find something enjoyable here.

In short: this is a game that's not as smart as it thinks it is. 

I wanted to enjoy the game, but there are lots of TBS games which do the whole roguelite thing a whole lot better: Into the Breach, Depth of Extinction, Dread Nautical, and Overland for example. And while Invisible Inc certainly has as much polish as any of these titles, it lacks in substance.

My biggest complaint with it is that, despite looking like it's a deep and complex game, it only really lends itself to one style of play. Items, characters, and programs are completely unbalanced, bottlenecking the player into using the same strategies and same loadouts every playthrough if they want to succeed. Any deviation from the norm results in swift and unfair failure. Too many options, too little substance.

Most of my experienced/expert mode playthroughs devolved into me failing on the 3rd or 4th mission because I misclicked, or because of some unforeseen bullshit which the game threw at me. As an example, sometimes guards will show up from behind corridors which you have no possible way of searching. Sometimes the game will throw an armored guard at you, despite you having no way of knocking out that guard yet. In such a situation, what are you supposed to do, except die and retry the game from the very beginning? Usually, a roguelite is supposed to foresee issues like this arising, but apparently, Invisible Inc never thought to do so.

Enemies will always outnumber you, often 6:1. This is a problem when your only weapons have a cooldown of 3 turns. I get that it's a "stealth" game, but there's no real option for being stealthy when all of your avenues for escape are completely blocked off. Your only real options most of the time are 1) die or 2) escape the mission without obtaining all the loot available. And if you choose 2), then you'll be undersupplied for future missions. 

It's also way too unforgiving, even for a roguelite. Characters are knocked out in one single attack. This is extremely problematic when your party size is a paltry 2 characters. Thus, if you make even 2 mistakes, or get screwed by 2 bouts of dumb luck vis-a-vis procedural generation, then congratulations: game over. The only way to truly avoid these situations is to utilize a very specific loadout, or get lucky with loot. 

Item-wise, Stim Packs and Cloaking Devices are absolutely essential, and are the only items which make the game remotely playable. On the character front, Internationale is head and shoulders above everyone else. What's the fun in customizing different parties if my party size is only 2, and I'm effectively FORCED into using one specific character for every single playthrough?

I could probably figure out ways to consistently clear the harder difficulties if I had the patience to deal with all the game's frustrations. But there are more interesting games to play, and better ways for me to spend my time.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
Randomness. The best and worst of [i]Invisible[/i] is the randomness. You will lose [b][i]a lot[/i][/b] as you are trying to learn. Sometimes tactics…sometimes dumb luck. Dumb luck get you killed? That’s it. Start over. These challenges made it interesting enough to keep starting new runs even after failing 15-20 times.
[hr][/hr]
[i]Invisible[/i] is a Roguelike, turn-based, stealth game that relies very, [b][i]very[/i][/b] heavily on randomness for nearly everything. The intro screen warning was completely correct, you will fail…a lot. Many failures will happen because of dumb luck. Normally, I hate that. After ~10 hours, I figured I was going to vote [i]Invisible[/i] down, but I found myself continuing to hit restart until I finally was good (and lucky) enough to finish a game on Experienced. Since [i]Invisible[/i] managed to hold my attention, despite a mechanic that normally causes me to throw my controller, I figured it deserved the thumbs up.

Gameplay is smooth and [i]mostly[/i] intuitive. Picking up how to play is easy, but mastery comes from figuring out how to best combine your skills, knowledge of enemy behavior, hacking abilities, and gear. Mission difficulty scales nicely, and the challenge is figuring out how to use what gear is randomly available to the best of your ability.

Graphics are good, but the music is the real prize. The excellent score never got old despite 30-ish hours of playtime.

A single (successful) playthrough is only 5-8 hours. This is about perfect. Long enough to feel like you developed a good team and accomplished something. Short enough that getting completely screwed by randomness doesn’t feel too wasted.

The one gameplay thing that bugged the ever-living crap out of me was the non-intuitive turn order. The first unit to go is always the last unit from the previous turn. Plus, the click-to-select isn’t very clean. No matter how awesome you are with a mouse (I’m only medium-awesome), you still fail to select something ~10-20% of the time. Embarrassingly, I lost way too many missions because I moved the wrong agent, or didn’t notice the objective never actually went into my inventory.

There is no going back. I’m a bonehead. I’ll make bonehead moves here and there…or I won’t notice I have the wrong character selected…etc. There is no pre-turn autosave or pre-mission autosave. I mean, I get it…if I was the shmuck who gave a dumb order, that’s on me. But I really don’t like having my game ruined because of a gameplay error…or when you click “go” and your brain instantly screams a deep, slow [b]Nnnnnnnnoooooooo![/b] 

There is a "rewind" button that let's you correct a mistake one round back, but you only get to use it ~3 times. While this might seem like a good option for boneheads like me...you will probably [b]really[/b] need those in a later mission to prevent getting screwed by randomness. A very limited undo button would go a long way to making the game safe for me...along with copious [i]Warning[/i] labels.

There is an option when you start your game to allow “Redo Mission”…but the game ridicules you if you select that, saying, [i]That’s not how the game is meant to be played[/i].  I didn’t select it, but I should have. I enjoy games more if I’m not worried about gameplay glitches…or being a bonehead.

Finally…randomness is both the best, and worst, part of [i]Invisible[/i]. I’m not talking “chance of success.” Actions always succeed…or you know why they won’t (like armor). Everyone gets knocked out or killed in one hit. Randomness is in the available missions, mission layout, type/location of enemy spawn, and gear. This is good because no two playthroughs will be the same, and you have to adapt your approach based on what is available. Not getting good weapon drops? Adapt your team to become the ultimate ninjas. Get lots of good hacking early? Use that to give you better intel and planning instead of gear for more diverse agents.

Randomness can also be a curse. Most Roguelikes let you plan how to approach the game. Your agent who is all about cyber might not get any useful drops. One mission, enemies might spawn on the other side of the map…the next, three enemies spawn in the room you are using to hide from patrols. You might not get any armor piercing weapons. If that happens, you almost can’t deal with late game baddies, and the final mission will be nearly impossible. This randomness makes it very difficult to play when you are learning. You will fail frequently, and early on you won’t know if you lost because your tactics sucked…or if it was just dumb luck. I really don’t like this. If I lose, I want my lumps and bruises to be a lesson.

Some people claim there is a magic strategy to always win. That’s too bad, because despite how annoying the randomness can be, the only real fun I had was in trying to adapt to what I was given. [i]Invisible[/i] would have become really boring if I was doing the same thing every run.

Even after 500 (geez) hours of playing, I still find the story engaging and the levels difficult. Quick Description:
-Invisible, Inc. is a creative, well designed, and extremely fun game designed by Klei Entertainment.  This is a turn based, tactical, strategy game that will test your ability to think quickly, and make tough decisions.  I loved the Mark of the Ninja, and this game shares a lot of the great characteristics of that game.  This is an easy game to recommend to anyone that enjoys stealth based strategy games.

What's Good:
-This is a gorgeous game visually.  Klei really outdid themselves here.  I think this game looks even better visually than the Mark of the Ninja.  Invisible, Inc. opts for a more futuristic, almost cyberpunk theme and setting.  You will be breaking into state of the art facilities w/ cameras, security guards, armed robots, and many other high tech things.  The characters all look distinct, and the animations are also top notch.
-This is a highly skilled game that will challenge you ever single level.  I think that the devs did a great job of finding new and innovative ways to challenge you as you get deeper into the game.  You'll need to learn how to avoid the security guards, hack the cameras and locks, and work together w/ your partner to collect as much data as possible, before escaping.  I learned something new every level that I played.
-The learning curve is fairly steep initially b/c of the amount of information you'll need to take in.  Fortunately, all of the information is easily accessible to you.  You'll quickly figure out how to navigate the facilities, hack the systems, and collects as many goodies as possible.  
-There are a bunch of different agents and tons of weapons/enhancements that you can either find or purchase.  There are always several ways to complete a given mission.  Stealth is the name of the game, but if you want to go guns blazing or knock every enemy out, that also gets the job done.
-This is another game that has a ton of value and will keep ppl on their toes for many hrs.  I played for just under 6 hrs, and I barely scratched the surface.  If you want to complete everything and unlock all the agents, it will likely take you at least 20-30 hrs.

Could Use Some Changes:
-This is technically a roguelight but it plays more like a traditional linear game that forces you to start over if you lose all of your agents.  Although, there are lots of agents and tons of cool 007 toys to play w/, their isn't a ton of diversity between runs.  This is mostly b/c the agents are basically the same, except they start off w/ slightly different base stats or tools.  You can use any tool/weapon w/ any agent as far as I'm aware so this limits replayability a bit.
-The learning curve is steeper than the average game.  There is quite a bit of information to take in on your first playthrough.  The tutorial is okay, but isn't as comprehensive as I'd like.  I suspect the devs want players to experiment and learn on their own.  This may make less experienced players feel a bit intimidated early on.
-As cool as this game is, it also feels very familiar.  There are a ton of turn based strategy games on the market, and Invisible, Inc. doesn't really add anything new to the genre.

Consensus:
-Solid Game (Tier 3 and makes up 35% of my reviews).  Invisible, Inc. is a really easy game to recommend to pretty much anyone, but especially turn based stealth fans.  Klei Entertainment seems to never miss when it comes to strong game design, unique visual presentation, and engaging gameplay.  Invisible, Inc. is another labor of love that every Indie fan should give a try.

Invisible Inc is basically Spy Chess: The Game; another triumph of game design and audiovisual excellence from the indominable Klei. Set in a near-future world of mega-corps and bionic enhancements, your team of operatives must infiltrate a series of increasingly fortified enemy lairs to retrieve resources, weaken enemy capabilities, and ultimately defeat your nefarious corporate foes by, ah, ascending an AI to godhood.

Individual missions play out as top-down tactical games of cat-and-mouse between your operatives and an interlocking web of enemy guards, surveillance cameras and security systems. Things start quiet and escalate as the passage of time, enemy alerts and completion of objectives increases the facility’s alarm level, until murderous robots and corporate goons are pouring from their lairs to hound your agents to the exfiltration point. This lends every encounter a compelling arc of emergent narrative, and delicious risk-reward calculations as you jeopardise everything for just one more gadget or bit of currency. Progress within missions as well as between them carries over, you see, and stealing a powerful bit of enemy technology or rescuing a superior addition to your roster will bolster your chances of success for the rest of every short-ish campaign. While failure can be frequent and punishing in this unforgiving game, pulling off a perfect heist as the net closes and the excellent music builds to a crescendo is about as pulse-pounding as 2D turn-based tactics can get.

Feeding into each mission is a meta-game of time and resource management, as you jetset around the globe selecting more-or-less challenging and rewarding missions in preparation for the final showdown. Mission difficulty escalates as time passes, meaning you’ll sometimes fluff a campaign and leave yourself with essentially no chance of success, forcing a restart. Over repeated campaigns, this can rob the tame early missions of some of their excitement and challenge. On the other hand, the mid- to late-game usually remain rock solid even after numerous replays; only occasionally will you run into a brick wall of difficulty. Invisible Inc is relatively successful – for a stealth game – at making failure interesting, with plenty of options for clawing victory from the jaws of defeat, as well as offering interesting trade-offs regarding what, or who, you’ll sacrifice in interests of the greatest chance at your final victory. Designed for repeated playthroughs, the procedural generation is mostly great, but can lend some levels a same-y feeling, although you’ll likely start skipping the somewhat generic cyberpunk plot after your first couple of runs through.

Overall, Invisible Inc is a unique and hugely compelling stealth tactics game, with all of the visual flare and game design excellence you’d expect from Klei. Same-y levels, a forgettable plot, and punishing difficulty which can lead to repeated campaign restarts perhaps hold it back from all-time classic status, but offers dozens of hours of fun in a captivating stealth sandbox before you’ll tire of it.

I would highly recommend this game for fans or stealth games or tactical RPGs. I would also recommend it even if you aren't fans of existing games in those genres.

I don't really love any stealth games or tactical RPGs, but I've always liked the ideas of those genres, and this game fulfills what I want from those types of games. 

Turn-based gameplay is a surprisingly good fit for stealth, as it allows you to pull of corny movie-like sneaking around. You can elegantly move your agents around guards, instead of just waiting for the guards to move away like in most realtime games (in realtime games it's generally to risky or unclear to weave around guard's line of sight). That's the biggest strength of this game, you're never forced to wait around. In fact, you can't wait around, because the longer you stay in a level, the more dangerous it becomes. You might not like the game if you don't like timers, but I find it really exciting, and you never just "run out of time", the level just becomes more threatening.

This game is also rarely a slog like a lot of tactical RPGs. Since you don't need to kill people, there's never a boring part of a battle where you're just finishing people off. Almost every turn is exciting, and once you find the objective, you just need to escape the level. Killing is a tactical option, but not a requirement.

I'm not a fan of roguelikes at all, but this game is a very very good one, and it hardly even feels like a roguelike to me. There are randomly generated levels and permadeath, but the campaign is several hours long, and you're given multiple retrys on the normal difficulty. As someone who's completely sick of rougelikes, these are welcome design choices, and if you DO like permadeath you can play on a harder difficulty. I never feel RNG-screwed in terms of trying to build up my team with items and abilities, although you'll need to learn that a lot of items are nearly useless.

Again, I'd highly recommend this game to anyone who likes stealth, tactical RPGS, or just wants a really unique game.

[h1]Invisible, Inc Review[/h1]

[i]**Spoiler free**[/i]

[i]UPDATE: I did notice that when playing Endless Mode, about once per sitting, the SFX would cut out, my monitor would go black, and my computer would become unresponsive, forcing me to do a force reboot. I haven't had that problem doing anything else, so I'm assuming this is some kind of bug with the game. Which is lame because I've been having so much fun with this game.[/i]

[u]Quick Summary:[/u] Invisible Inc. is a fun and challenging turn-based stealth game. Somehow it seemed more complicated at first than I was anticipating, and definitely benefits from playing through a few levels first to learn the mechanics. But the procedural maps, meaningful decisions, helpful UI, game-replay unlocks, and a story that hits the right tone makes what could have been a repetitive game into a challenging and addictive one that I keep coming back to.

[u]Gameplay:[/u] The game is a turn-based stealth game, and handles this genre-mix well. You play through a series of missions that you get to pick, which all basically play out the same way: find your objective and get out. It’s a fun core gameplay loop since the procedurally generated maps throw you against new problems every time. Plus each mission type gives you different rewards.

You have an AI hacker that allows you to disable or convert enemy security systems, but each hack requires power. You start with two operatives per play-through, with the ability to rescue two more by the end. Operatives can be upgraded in 4 categories with credits: speed, strength, hacking, anarchy. Each one improves an attribute, but sometimes they're are also required at a certain level to use certain items.

Enemies are highly encouraged to be KO’d and not killed. A KO will last a few turns before they return alerted. Pinning KO’d enemies stalls their recovery time. If an enemy "notices" you, they will check out the area. If they see you, you get one movement space to hide or take them out. If you can’t, your operative gets taken out.

Every turn you take increases the alarm by one slot. Every 5 slots increases the alarm by a level, which introduces new obstacles to completing the level. It really serves the race-against-the-clock story theme and makes for some tough decisions: is it worth spending more time to steal credits and loot? Or is it smarter to finish the level as sooner?

This is the strength of the game: Difficult decisions. Your decisions matter. There might not be enough time, money, carrying slots, incognito power, or some combination to do everything you’d like to do. So you have to make well thought out decisions to complete the levels successfully. It's pretty fun.

Also, after finishing a play-through (successfully or not) you receive XP which goes towards unlocking new Operatives and Incognito powers! I think that’s awesome. More games should do this. In other words, the replay value is great.

[u]User Interface:[/u] The UI is very helpful in this game. The hud has most of the information you’ll need (you can open a character sheet to see operative stats). And actions you can take towards objects/enemies pop-up next to them on the field.

But the most helpful thing is all the viewing mode options. The art style is in a style that's kind of thin and tall. So the map is way too cluttered with the default view. But they give you all sorts of ways to get around this. My favorite is the “low wall mode” (shortcut T) which I turn on immediately every game. There is also a tactical mode by holding down ALT, and you can rotate the orthogonal angle with E and W. Personally, the “Low Wall Mode” is more than enough, and makes for a more convenient time. Very helpful visual features.

[u]Difficulty:[/u] I recommend starting in easy to learn how the game works, and then increasing it later. Some things you need to stumble through to understand.

[u]Atmosphere:[/u] The story centers around a secret organization that is attacked by some totalitarian force. It’s all a bit vague, and perhaps bland? But it does a great job at serving the gameplay. It’s just enough story to sell you on your role and mission. Basically the story is very light. The art style is hit or miss. Personally the emphasis on stealth, and the music to support it, is what gives this game its character. You really feel like a secret agent breaking in and getting out, either totally unnoticed or just in time. Cool concept.

[u]Conclusion:[/u] Invisible Inc is a great package. It has challenging stealth and strategy, immersive decisions, a fun story concept, and good replay value. Recommend!

98390801.review:
[i] Invisible, Inc. [/i] was my first introduction into XCOM style, turn based tactics games, and it was also one of my first introductions to the roguelike genre, with its permadeath, random level generation, and fail-forward progression. All things I love! So I must admit, I have something of a soft spot for the game. 

Just like many of Klei Entertainment's other games, it's very stylish. The dark, geometric figures of the characters are wonderfully detailed, with accents of color and light. The animations capture a lot of personality, too.

The story is solid. The AI system that your firm relies on, Incognita, is dying due to a lack of power following a corporate assault, and it's your job to get her back online. You have to strike back at the corporations by stealing from them, and by finding a new host for Incognita, in order to get the firm back on its feet. The game is undoubtedly inspired by the cyberpunk genre, but it's a touch more cyber than punk. The world the game takes place in, whose lore can be discerned through various voicelines and files, is just detailed enough to capture one's imagination and lend to the credibility of the corporations' power.

As far as sound goes, alarms blare, robots and turrets chirp and hum eerily, footsteps thunder, guards chatter.  Gunshots ring out across the halls. It all works. The soundtrack, though short, is full of hopeful melodies, menacing synths, and pulsing beats, and really enhances the atmosphere and tension.

Gameplay is not very XCOM like, despite the similarities. Enemies need direct line of sight to fire at you, meaning you must have no cover, and for them to even get a shot, must either stumble into you or directly seek you out after having been aggro'd. Considering guns and ammo are scarce and killing incurs a cleanup fee, you will mostly be reliant on avoiding detection altogether, using melee sneak attacks to knock out guards and guns for only the most troublesome (well, unless you are playing with Draco). Random levels mean you don't always know what to expect from enemy spawns and patrol patterns, or the positions of objectives. Difficulty wise, it's hard, but doesn't usually feel unfair.

This game has some shortcomings. Certain builds and playstyles are much more effective than others, making certain items and agents have little to no utility. You will likely lose a few times before you find the winning combinations.

All told, Invisible Inc. is a very stylish, exciting, and mechanically solid game with a good amount of replay value. It's relatively pretty short, though sweet, with a surprising amount of depth and richness both in its mechanics, its world, and its artwork. It feels like a classic example of independent developers forgoing the bloat so typical in this industry, by cleverly doing more with less.

This is tense and challenging turn-based tactical stealth game. You have 1-4 agents who you must move through a facility, hacking equipment and stealing stuff, while staying one step ahead of the guards. The game features a sleek animated look and good voice acting. And for a turn-based game it can be surprisingly intense: when there are two guards and a scientist in the room looking for you and your agent's only cover is a flower pot right in front of them, you may find your heart beating rapidly!

This is a hard game. You are given the bare minimum of resources to accomplish your missions, and you must learn to use them well. Every step your agents take through each guarded facility must be chosen carefully. What devices you should hack and when; whether or not you should spend a precious attack turn to take that guard down; these are serious decisions.

Fortunately the game features a well-thought-out difficulty curve. On lower difficulties, guard patrol patterns are simpler and more predictable; the alarm level more forgiving; and the player gets more "do-overs." Once you master the basics, you can tweak these settings for a stiffer challenge.

One cool thing about this game is that it features almost no randomness beyond the layout of the levels and the starting positions of the guards. Once you learn these things, there should be few surprises. Your agents will live and die based on your own tactical decision making, not thanks to bad rolls.

Very cool game that calls for a lot of patience and precision. Deep gameplay that I keep coming back to (I've put well over 150 hours in now). Highly recommended.

Act 1 First Impressions: So far, so good! 

I'll update this with a final comment on the storyline when I finish it, but speaking from a pure gameplay, art, and design perspective, this game is overall pretty excellent. 

The Good
- The art style and animation is an absolute delight. It's gorgeous, seriously. I could get used to the pop cyberpunk look of bright, detailed models.
- The characters I've found so far are all interesting, with their own unique quirks that lend themselves to specific playstyles on an agent-by-agent basis (an already good game design concept turned up to 10.5 here).
- Controls are simple and quite intuitive. Item/ability cooldowns rather than use limits really lend themselves well to the overall gameplay.
- Level design is on a procedural basis, so no two missions will ever be exactly the same as far as layout goes, which is a solid nod toward to feel that the game is going for. You know just enough to know you have a target somewhere, but it's up to your agents in the field to actually figure everything out on site.

That being said
- Level design is on a procedural basis, so you'll find a lot of reused assets, and none of the different corps seem to have their own truly aesthetic, which is a definite missed opportunity.
- Mission variety could be better. You have a slate of mission types (a rescue mission, and a couple minor variations on the smash-and-grab principle) that don't vary (at least up to this point, so this may simply be an Act 1 quibble rather than a full-game quibble).
- Music is your standard cyberpunk background music, with little to nothing in the way of audio cues for any sort of events, good, bad, or otherwise. It maintains a low level of tension during missions, but that's about it. Another missed opportunity for creating unique corps (I know, I know, unique and corporate are generally anathema to each other, but nobody confuses Coke for Pepsi either).

Overall
It's a low rent, roguelike Phantom Doctrine/Shadowrun, and that's not a slight on the game in any way. I definitely recommend checking it out.

It's like Invisible Inc is designed to be deliberately frustrating for every wrong reason. Once again, the game tries to be challenging by just not giving players anything to work with. Even worse is moves that are supposed to give crucial map information, don't. You can peer through a door into the next room, but half the time it won't show you the guard or the camera, only that the room is covered in survailence. GREAT! So how am I supposed to breach if I can't even see the camera to deactivate it and the guard is going to pop me the instant I open the door?

All the hackable objects have no useful descriptions and no indication of what effect they'll have on the map if you hack them. Power is a precious resource. I shouldn't have to spend power to hack every generator on the map to find the one that shuts down the lasers! 

Objectives aren't highlighted and the game gives you no layout of the map. Imagine the Navy Seals raiding Taliban Strongholds without first spending months practicing in mock floor plans until they're as familiar with the layout as the people who live there! And you're supposed to be commanding a super elite squad of infiltrators! DUR HUR! Let's just go in blindly and get us all killed! That's exactly what happens 9/10 times. Even the original Thief had the decency to at least give players a crude drawing of the level with some annotations in the margins.

And of course these developers think they're being cute by randomly generating everything, including map layout. Because the developers are so lazy they have to have an algorithm design their levels for them, some maps are just going to be generated in a way that screws you over, full stop. Meaning you're @#$%ed from the get go, the only solution is to die.

You'd think that'd be easy to accomplish in a game like this. But no. Because for no reason, there is no option to start the level over. You have to find armed guards to suicide your entire squad... THEN you're given the option to start the level over. And this process can take over 20 clicks. But I guess pulling up a menu and clicking "restart" in two clicks like every other game ever would make too much sense and not be ZOMG HARRD CORREE enough.

And because you'll be playing the same levels over and over again like a slot machine, the same dialog sequences play at the beginning of each level. They cannot be skipped through. And after the characters finally shut up, all sorts of pop ups about objectives and @#$% start popping up! For @#$% sake! I know the objectives! There are only like four of them in the whole game and any idiot can figure them out! Stop cramming text boxes in my face that I've already read twelve dozen times and let me get on with it!

So the whole point is that you die and get to keep experience and any characters you've unlocked and blah blah blah blah blah. Except the game is only "hard" because it's random and offers players few options in combat. [b]Invisible, Inc.[/b] is a run-based, procedurally generated, turn-based, tactics game, set in the very cyberpunk future of 2074.  You play as the Operator of Invisible, Inc, a private team of stealth operatives on the verge of being wiped out by the combined might of of a group of rival super-corporations.

The gameplay is reminiscent of tactics-based shooters like [b]XCOM[/b], where you give orders to your units on a square-tile based map. The big difference is that the game revolves around stealth and hacking: enemy units are very dangerous and your opportunities to kill them are infrequent and strongly disincentivized.

A single run of Invisible, Inc. takes about 7 hours, and consists of 6-9 prep missions and the final mission. The format is similar to [b]FTL[/b] and [b]Into the Breach[/b]: each run is randomly generated, and you play until you win or lose. The runs are interesting enough that I found myself thinking about what I was going to do on my next run while I was playing the current one, and that's high praise indeed.

Every decision you make has consequences. Like Into the Breach or [b]Slay the Spire[/b], it's a high-information game: Mousing over an enemy unit or piece of hardware will tell you everything you need to know about it. The immediate results of every move you make are displayed before you make them. Also, even though the contents of the levels are random, the results of the actions you take are not. When engaging in a melee takedown or a ranged shot, there's no chance of a random miss or failure.

If you're a fan of turn-based and run-based games, you'll probably really enjoy Invisible, Inc.

I picked this up a while back, after finishing XCOM 2 and feeling hungry for similar titles. I kept it on the shelf for a few years, and was hesitant to play it having decided I wasn't fond of the 'art direction' any longer. Still I decided to boot it up and give it a try.

I was not disappointed in this games ability to deliver intense and addictive game play. This isn't a game that is trying to be another XCOM type, which has already seen a lot of games try to emulate its popular turned based tactical combat through the typical use of the cover and surprise to overwhelm enemies. A formula that worked very well, but which has started to become overused in the market.

Instead, Invisible Inc. has reinvented itself along a stealth variant that forces you to consider each move carefully, with the focus on being 'Invisible'. Weapons, while available, play a somewhat limited role. Instead, its up to you to plan your moves carefully, peaking around corners or checking behind doors before moving into the open. Throughout each level, you can risk searching for loot which give you additional advantages, such as augmented abilities which boost movement or hacking abilities. Dont take too long though, as the security level of the mission increases as the turns go by. Increases security levels bring about more cameras becoming activated and the deployment of additional guards among a few other things. This pressure ensures that you make decisions between searching for loot and completing the mission, as you can easily get wiped if caught out in the open. 

The incorporation of 'hacking' and the AI system adds an additional layer of complexity as you utilize your AI to remove barriers, open safes, disable cameras & turrets, or hack terminals which contain software programs (daemons) which can impede your mission by adding penalties additional penalties. 

The inclusion of a number of upgradeable skills, additional agents that can be freed and a variety of different equipment to be found help ensure that game has some feeling of progression has more developed agents are needed for increasingly difficult missions. The missions themselves are interesting, aside from special missions, you can select between detention centers, cybernetics labs, and security vaults to name a few. 82417037.review:
[b]X-Com+Metal Gear Solid=Invisible, Inc. [/b]

This game is notable in several respects that might be not immediately obvious:
1. Because of very limited number of missions (between five and eight, not counting the introductory one and the final missions. DLC gives you some more time, but the game gets more difficult and throws new tricks into the mix as well) that can be done in a single campaign, getting overpowered is extremely difficult compared to X-Com and it's other imitators, where you only have any serious time pressure at the start, if at all. This solves some of the many balance issues prevalent in X-Com clones. The player gets more powerful with each mission, but the enemies don't lag behind, and choosing the missions and benefits that they grant is never as simple as picking *the biggest shiny thing*. [b]You need everything you can get. And you have very limited opportunities to get it.[/b] 

2. RNG level-generator is among the best I've seen since 1999. It consistently creates new, tricky levels using very limited number of assets. And it's never a straight line to the objective and exit. Explore, and loot everything you can carry away, or you might not get enough resourses for the final missions.

3. The guards behave very predictably, with very few random elements to their actions, and it's the player's job to manipulate them. The player actually controls everything and everyone in game. The only difference is some pieces the player controls directly (hacking interface and Invisible inc agents) amd some— indirectly (guards and all kinds of hack-able devices).

4.The game might be easy to learn but harder to master. Still, even on expert+ it is always fair, and the player won't lose just because of some dice roll gone wrong.

5. Invisible, Inc. was balanced around Expert difficulty. Unless you've never [b][i]ever[/i][/b] played turn-based tactics games I recommend you start playing on Expert. Otherwise you'll miss some of the more exciting features, like incremental alarm gain that doesn't allow you to sit in a corner for unlimited amount of turns. You have to act. But, unlike in Firaxis' XCom 2 that doesn't mean you have to rush. And even when the level is on full alert, you don't fail anything—sometimes it might be even benefical to raise the alarm higher. Why? I won't spoil it.

6. The game is very well balanced. Every character and most items are consistently useful, more or less so depending on your playstile.

7.While it's a stealth game that constantly cautions you against fighting guards head on, with the right agents and items you can litter levels with dead and knocked out bodies, blaizing through the level like a lightning, or methodically clearing out hostiles one by one. Going for kills might be difficult and costly in early game, but in the later stages it's often the easier and faster option.

TL;DR: One of the best  turn-based tactics games I've ever played.
Well designed, well balanced, well polished.
Buy DLC if you like the base game—it's an honest, proper expansion pack.

An interesting twist on roguelikes, but one that ultimately ends up feelings a little samey to me after a while.

The gameplay itself is solid. The stealth tactics, sneaking about, and hacking are all well done. There is much satisfaction to be had in successfully completing a mission right under the enemy's nose. It's a fairly standard turn based affair in that your team has action points that they use to accomplish things, but unique in that it's a stealth game.

The roguelike bits come in when you lose-- you unlock new characters, items, and hacking abilities when you finish a run (be it winning or losing). The problem that I had here, and my biggest complaint with the game, is that I'm not really sure how much the different characters / items / whatever are going to change up the feel of the game. Each mission that I played felt pretty much the same, and while that 'same' was good, I was still tired of it by the end of the campaign.

The art direction is well done, and the game performs and functions great. No issues on a technical front. one thing I did quite like is that you could run it in a window and resize the window to whatever you wanted. I thought that was slick. The game features a multitude of difficulties and allows you to customize many options pertaining to how hard the game is, which is great.

So in the end, while I think Invisible Inc is a good game, I didn't feel like there was enough variation to really warrant coming back to it over and over, which is something that I think a successful roguelike needs. I still had a good time with it, but I don't see myself going through run after run hoping to unlock the new macguffin and see how it'll change the game.

I love tactical turned based games and I have played tons of them. I think Invisible, Inc. actually has the tightest and most rewarding gameplay than any other tactical game I've played for 3 reasons:

1. The game basically removes the luck factor completely, but retains as much difficulty as you want. 

2. The game implements the best original tactical concept I've encountered which is the "rewind" system. Basically, you get a limited number of whole turn undos, but once you used them up your screwed. This gives you a margin of error ( the number of rewinds can be changed depending on if you want the game to be easier or harder), but still keeps you on your toes as there is no reload past saves option.

3. The game is incredible tense and engaging. Because you can't just make a quick save file and reload of things go to hell, every decision you make feels heavy and significant. If your down to your last rewind, or have none left, every movement must be perfect or your going to lose your whole game. 

This game has created a beautiful and, in my experience, unprecedented harmony between difficulty a fairness that keeps you on edge at every moment. 

Also, just be aware that the campaign is extremely short, only about 3-5 hours (though it may take you longer to beat it as you stare at your screen second guessing all your thoughts about what to do next). This game is meant to be replayed using different loadouts and options. It is not a narrative experience, rather it is pure gameplay perfection. There is also an endless mode where you see how long you can survive with escalating difficulty that goes far beyond the campaign.

An indie mix between [b]Deus Ex GO[/b] and [b]Firaxis Games[/b]' [b]XCOM[/b]. With a tiny little bit of [b]Volume[/b] added to the formula. That's pretty much it. Well, aside from the fact that the entire design here was stolen from good ol' [b]Shadow Watch[/b]. But OK, OK, that's a lot of names. Let me start from the beginning. First of all – what the heck is [b]Invisible, Inc.[/b]? [b]Invisible, Inc.[/b] is a stealth-oriented tactical game, in which you control a group operatives in order to complete missions. Like I said, it looks almost identical to good ol' [b]Shadow Watch[/b] (feel free to check it on [b]GOG[/b] if you missed it back in the days, it's totally worth your time), only unlike [b]Shadow Watch[/b], you should not expect much shooting here.

Instead, the game focuses on stealth. While using [b]XCOM[/b]-like [b]UI[/b] (I'm talking about remake, of course, not the original game by [b]Mythos Games[/b]), you'll try to sneak past guards in a [b]Commandos[/b]-like way. Only, unlike [b]Commandos[/b], this game doesn't really have enough freedom and ends up feeling more like [b]Volume[/b] as the result. In other words, the entire game is just a series of corridors that look and feel exactly the same. You can use special powers, though, but those are very limited. Which leads to a very unpleasant result. See, I already mentioned [b]Deus Ex GO[/b], right? And we all know that it's a mobiles-oriented puzzle game. While this one was supposed to provide you a proper tactical experience. But the thing is – with very limited arsenal of powers and pretty small maps, the game ends up feeling more like a puzzle. In other words, it feels a lot like [b]Deus Ex GO[/b], where you either guess exactly what to do, or die in agony. And features like “rewind” only add to the effect.

It's not like I can't enjoy something like that, though. I liked [b]Deus Ex GO[/b]. Sure, I don't think I'll ever want to re-play it, but it was fun to beat once. The problem is... this game isn't. That's just it about [b]Invisible, Inc.[/b]. [i]It isn't fun.[/i] Like... at all. And not because story here sucks. Well, it sure does, but that's not the problem. I'm not one of those people who always look for complicated stories in games. I'm with [b]John Carmack[/b] here. It's nice to have an interesting story in game, but seriously, as long as gameplay is good, “[i]our princess is in another castle[/i]” is more than enough. What's the [i]real[/i] problem here is that [b]Invisible, Inc.[/b] does two things wrong. First – it's one of those games that aim for customizable campaigns and replayability instead of complicated pre-made stuff. Nothing's wrong with that and the formula works perfectly in roguelike titles, but together with the second thing? It just ruins the game. See, [b]Invisible, Inc.[/b]? It just isn't comfortable enough.

It's one of those games, in which you'll fight with the [b]UI[/b] more than you'll fight with the enemies. Everything here is too small, you'll need to do a lot of needless actions to achieve the most basic things and it'll feel like everything's here was designed to make your life harder with no reason whatsoever. And in this case it reminds me of another tactical indie game - [b]All Walls Must Fall[/b]. There was so much good about that game, but it was so... bloody... uncomfortable that it was really hard to enjoy it. Like... [i]really[/i] hard. Same thing here. And as the result... [b]Invisible, Inc.[/b] just falls apart.

See, you'll be able to finish the smallest custom campaign here in only an hour. Without even trying hard. That's it. The entire game lasts only one hour. As long as you won't decide to make it longer by choosing the corresponding options and paying for [b]DLC[/b]. But the thing is – you won't. You won't want this game to be longer. You beat the hour-long campaign (that comes with only a couple of story-related cutscenes) and then that'll be it. The game just doesn't feel good enough to make you want to return to it. Sure, [b]Invisible, Inc.[/b] is far from being awful. Is it playable? Well, yeah. Totally. With nothing else to choose from, you'll be able to kill some time with it. It's not one of those “[i]OMG, it sucks butt![/i]” games. The problem is, it's nothing you'll choose willingly. It's one of those indie games that have nothing special about them and don't feel good enough to make you bother. If this game will cease to exist? Nobody would even notice. It's an [i]invisible[/i] game. For a reason. Dixi.

Invisible, Inc. is a turn-based "tactics" style game based on stealth and espionage rather than straight-up combat.  Like most of this developer's titles (and believe me when I say any game this dev puts out is worth a close look and a full-price purchase), the concept puzzled me at first (Oxygen Not Included: a 2d side-scrolling dwarf-fortress-like with physics simulation?  No way.  But I've got almost quadruple-digit hours in it.  A deck-building rogue-like with different decks for combat and conversation?  Bizarre.), but it totally works.  

The gameplay loop involves choosing a pair of starting characters with different skills and abilities, selecting procedurally missions with varying types of rewards and difficulty levels, and then progressing to the endgame after a certain number of missions have been played.  There's no way to grind missions to better prepare for the end-game, making your mission selections and your careful investment of very limited resources and opportunities crucial for success, in the spirit of other very fine procedurally generated games like FTL and Into the Breach that constantly keep you on the razor's edge between having just enough to squeak by and total disaster.  Like any great game of this type, you're constantly faced with difficult decisions.  Go back to rescue a downed teammate or complete your mission objective?  High-tail it out of a risky situation or risk it all to get a powerful hacking routine?  Dilemmas like this make Invisible, Inc a compelling and durable gaming experience, and I've long surpassed the three hours-per-dollar of enjoyment landmark in this game making it an incredible value at full price.

The visual style is clean and consistent throughout the experience, with a semi-realistic cell-shaded appearance to the art assets, and a distinct character design style that complements the surprisingly high-quality cut-scene animations that act as intro and outro to the game that could easily stand alone as an animated feature if they were longer (like 50x longer, they're pretty short) and more fleshed out.  Despite the short length of these animations they really sucked me into the story, which involves preserving an artificial intelligence after a private espionage contractor gets burned (I'm a sucker for any story that features an AI).  The game doesn't beat you over the head with the story, just gives you enough of a story to set the mood and provide interesting backgrounds and flavor text/VO to peruse later.

The music and sound design are also top-notch (something I always expect from this dev and am never disappointed), the music adds and subtracts track elements depending on the alarm level of the stage, adding driving drum and bass tracks to the mix when the threat level rises which is greatly effective at producing an absorbing and immersive experience.  The voice-over work is also extremely high quality, although there isn't a ton of it in the game, just enough to keep it interesting to listen to.

The core gameplay is challenging enough, but there are also higher difficulty levels with more constraints, and multiple things to unlock on subsequent playthroughs, which is why I've got nearly 70 hours logged in a game that only takes a few hours to complete.  Accepting different constraints and starting with hacking programs or characters that you wouldn't usually start with provides interesting and fresh gameplay challenges, since the way you approach your run with different character abilities *and combinations of character abilities* can wildly vary depending on what you start with.

Invisible, Inc. is worth a full-price purchase for anyone who enjoys turn-based tactics games, games based on stealth/espionage, novel gameplay types, cyberpunk, or procedurally generated games.  Check it out!

I'm rather suprised - in a positive way - by this game. Bought it because it was on sale and ended up playing it for 6h straight. I suppose comparing it to XCOM is inevitable, so lemme just get this out of the way. XCOM is much more combat-focused (I cannot speak for XCOM 2 onwards, though, haven't played those) and has a more "serious" feel to it. Invisible, however, focuses on stealth. You can do a mission without ever alerting a guard, a camera, or a drone, if you manage to do it. Engaging in combat is not required, and in fact it doesn't seem that the game encourages it. With each turn the alarm level increases, and some actions may raise it further and even trigger special defenses. The longer you take to complete a level, the higher the security level will be, and the tougher the measures that will be implemented (more cameras, more guards, more firewalls). 

Using lethal options will cause the security levels to be raised. As in Metal Gear, you can try go Rambo, but the game doesn't seem to encourage you. You will probably want to study your options, use your action points sparingly, and coordinate your agents according to their abilities and inventories. The difficulty of the missions increases as you progress in the game, and so far I haven't had the option to go back and do a lower-level mission to farm for credits, more abilities to our agency's AI etc. This seems to be coherent with the plot. The Corporations become increasingly aware of our operations, so new operations become increasingly harder. 

I wasn't too impressed by animation of Invisible, Inc. at first. Combined with the voice acting, and I'm not saying either of these are bad, I felt like I was watching The Incredibles. The clichéd British accent of the agency's founder is a bit annoying in my opinon, but it does seem to fit.

The plot isn't a thing to be admired either; it's a generic cyberpunk setting. It does have a Watch Dogs (at times, explicitely) feel to our agency. It's like Gen Z striking against The Corporation, hooraaay! To be fair, this is tempered with some agents with different backgrounds, such as an ex-corporate background.

You will be able to upgrade your agents' abilities (speed, hacking, anarchy, strength) and your AI's capabilities. You do that with the credits you earn; it doesn't rely on XP. During the operations, you also have the option to access terminals where you can buy/sell items (new agents don't have any items on them, which renders them not as useful as you'd expect), augmentations etc., and other terminals will allow you to buy/sell abilities for your AI.

I can't say I've encountered actual cons so far, and I'm a very critical person. The things I didn't appreciate much so far aren't necessarily bad; I just mentioned a couple of things that weren't particularly pleasing to my personal taste. I view these not-so-great things in a very positive light, though. The thing about this game is that it seems to be perfect in a philosophic, Aristotelian sense (yes, bear with me). It's not overly ambitious; it apparently achieves its full potential in what it seems to have gone for. I'm sure that people who have played Obsidian's Outer Worlds were quite frustrated. The game seems to have gone for so much more than what it was able to accomplish in actuality. Not a bad game, it's just insipid, unintersting, frustrating - this is Obsidian after all, where is the top-notch writing and interesting characters and choices? In that sense, Invisible is much more successful.

I bought this game on sale with little to back my decision other than, "hm, seems alright, I can get some more trading cards with this and then sell them and upgrade my Pillars of Eternity Badge", and I think this may be one of the rare cases where I got more than what I paid for. It's definitely worth it at full price. I'm not saying this will be the GOTY, to be sure, and I don't mean to exaggerate the qualities of this game, but it's a very fun and intelligent game, and I'd recommend it with no reservations.

game's legit. reminded me of transistor / mark of the ninja aesthetically and x-com gameplay wise. 

game has many different flavors depending on choices you make:

1) your team selection for your playthrough. you get two agents, each with a unique ability, and the different combinations have distinct strengths and weaknesses.

2) which stats you focus on upgrading for your agents, and in what order (focusing on maxing anarchy for example allows an agent to steal items from guards, and hence pay for more stuff down the road, although it makes early missions harder)

3) which type of mission you choose (getting items, getting augments, getting cash, rescuing hostages, or getting programs)

4) which corporation you choose to fight (they each have different units with different weaknesses/strengths, like armor or KO resistance, and also each corporation has different items their units drop that are related to the corporation type; i.e. the robot corp drops EMPs and accelerator chips and the military security corp drops flashbangs and pistols. Also they have different level layouts with different strategies: the robot corp will heavily favor sound alarms for example)

5) whether you choose quality or quantity with your mission selection. you have 72 hours to choose as many missions as you can. it takes 5-12 hours to travel to each mission, so you can make it to 7-13 missions. as you play through multiple times you'll get a feel for when it's best to go out of your way for a specific mission type.

and also two random factors:

1) procedural generation of the maps (some might be a linear stealth crawl, whereas others have the objective and exit on opposite ends of the map, requiring a fair bit of noisy running. every map can't be played the same)

2) which items / augments / programs drop / are available for sale on each level. (this can change up your strategy if you suddenly get a rare item or potent augment pairing you hadn't planned on)

that's 5 dimensions of meaningful decisions you make that shape the game, with some random elements thrown in to spice it up.

i don't normally get too excited about rogue-likes, but i would highly recommend this game. it's been a while since i played something new that was this fun.
