71048671.review:
[h1][u]The Short and Sweet[/u][/h1]
[u]Invisible, Inc.[/u] is a tactical turn-based stealth game, where the player takes control of up to four secret agents responsible for completing various assignments to help Invisible in its fight against the various corporations controlling the world. The gameplay seems simple in concept but enjoyably complicated in execution: agents must remain out of sight and complete their assignment without dying. Players are not given any information about the layout of the map beforehand, and every single level is randomly generated, allowing for a large amount of replay value.

Players must focus on remaining unseen by enemies using cover and intelligent movement, with nearly no options to deal with direct combat. Money and items must be stolen during missions, with an occasional offer from the vendor Monst3r, but not very often. This is the more pure form of risk / reward possible in a game, and makes the player consider if they should prioritize the objective or send an agent to loot a safe or nano-fabricator surrounded by enemy patrols. Every safe, nanofab, or server terminal missed could have been an immensely helpful asset to your missions moving forward.

[b][u]Pros[/u][/b]
[list]
[*] Very comprehensive core stealth gameplay.

[*] Challenges the player to overcome obstacles and make critical decisions, creating a rewarding experience to overcome in every mission.

[*] The usefulness of obtaining as much extra loot as possible gives more motivation to take risks, which in turn gives more depth to the gameplay.

[*] Every enemy corporation has their own style of security and enemies, which lets an intelligent player adapt to the enemy at hand before even entering a mission.

[*] The stylized visuals add a good feel to the game, and the music is pleasant to listen to, ramping up in intensity in response to intense situations a player may encounter.

[*] The DLC [u]Contingency Plan[/u] adds additional time and missions onto the campaign, which I very much enjoyed. This was the only part of the DLC I liked.
[/list]

[b][u]Cons[/u][/b]
[list]
[*] All of the loot, map layouts, and security systems are completely random. This means the difficulty of a specific playthrough can be heavily variable, and not always in a good way.

[*] If the “Restarts Allowed” option is not enabled, your entire playthrough can be completely ended by a single mission with bad luck. This is one of the most infuriating mechanics a game can have, and is never a good feature to have. Unless you enjoy the thrill of a sudden game over looming around every corner, always enable restarts.

[*] Most of the content enabled by the DLC, [u]Contingency Plan[/u], is not worth the price. The items and augments added are sub-par, while the enemies and security programs are much more punishing than those of vanilla. Essentially, it just adds more obstacles without giving you the tools to overcome these new challenges.
[/list]

[h1]Short Conclusion: Recommended
(Not Recommended for those that get frustrated easily)[/h1]

[h1][u]In-Depth Analysis[/u][/h1]

 [h1]Gameplay[/h1]
As previously mentioned, [u]Invisible, Inc.[/u] is a turn-based stealth game. The player controls agents on the field and are instructed to complete various objectives of the player’s choosing. While the map of which missions are available is randomly generated, the types of missions are consistent. There are detention centers, which can house allied agents ready to be rescued, or vault jobs that require access codes obtained from chief financial suite missions. The player must make the choice of which missions to enter based on what resources they think they require. Do you need more money? Do a vault job. Do you need tools? Break into a location with an advanced Nanofabricator. The choice is up to you, and each choice maters.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2134476653

Gameplay revolves around movement on a top-down viewed grid, with a focus on agent placement and avoiding enemy patrols & sightlines. Agents are given a limited amount of Action Points (AP), which determines their possible movement, along with other actions like predicting the movement of security forces. Not properly planning your AP can quickly leave you in hot water you might not be able to get out of. 

Enemy sightlines are indicated by the familiar cone of view, with special highlights to indicate areas that are watched, areas that are hidden from view, and areas that are just out of sight which will cause enemies to investigate. Line of sight is affected by objects strewn around the map, walls, and doors. Placement of your agents to avoid being seen during the enemy’s turn is critical to success.

While the art style is pleasant to look at, there is also a tactical view available at the tap of a button (Alt by default) that removes all extra distractions and shows just the raw info on the situation, like walls, doors, enemies, and cover.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2134475092

Another crucial aspect of the gameplay is your AI, Incognita, responsible for hacking into enemy security systems. Her programs allow her to take down firewalls on enemy objects, like cameras and nanofabricators. These programs require Power (PWR) and cannot function without the necessary amount. PWR can be found throughout consoles, but there are a limited amount per level. Enemy devices can also contain Daemons, which give negative debuffs to Incognita for a short amount of time if triggered. 

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story is good, but not very present. The premise is a world conquered by powerful, militaristic corporations, and the player works for an agency called Invisible that attempts to fight back. Invisible is caught off-guard during a raid and left with little resources, having to steal and evade the corporations in their attempt to salvage the agency.

This story is only told through very brief dialogues and limited cutscenes, which leave much to be desired. There is also data available in a few other ways, such as agent descriptions, but not enough to be satisfying. I wish there was more.

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
The stylized top-down view adds a lot to the gameplay, and the choice to not allow sight in areas that cannot be seen by a camera or agent puts pressure on the player to remember important information they can’t necessarily see at the moment. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=720632627

The art style is also quite good, with sharp angles and emphasis on advanced technology giving the intended feel of a corporate-run dystopia. I find it quite enjoyable.

However, the few cutscenes in the game seem to lack something to make them look particularly good. As it stands, they are just a cut below good, but are still decent enough to not detract from the experience.

[h1]Audio[/h1]
The voice acting is competent and crisp, with only a few lapses in quality during skippable cutscenes.

The music is great and ramps up in intensity when the game becomes more intense, starting out calm when the enemies are unaware but becomes incrementally more intense as more enemies become aware of your intrusion letting the player really get into the groove of the situation. 

[h1]Technical[/h1]
[u]Specs:[/u] GeForce 840m 2GB, 8GB Memory, i7 CPU, Windows 8.1

I encountered zero problems playing this game in 1080p with a good framerate.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[u]Invisible, Inc.[/u] is a great turn-based stealth game with a great atmosphere that sadly suffers from fits of terrible bad luck that can ruin the experience. Still, when the game isn’t screwing you with bad RNG, it is very enjoyable, and a satisfying challenge to overcome every time I boot it up.

Many people compare it to XCOM, but I don't see anyone mentioning one particular feature that XCOM: EU and XCOM 2 both missed.

There's an inherent issue with XCOM's turn-based combat; since the enemy is more powerful than you, and you don't know where they are, you tend to play defensively. XCOM: EU was like that. Your best option was to move a little, hide, and end your turn on Overwatch. It dragged the gameplay down and missions took longer than they needed to. XCOM 2 attempted to fix this by adding a mission timer; if you didn't finish the objective in X turns, you lost. This motivated more aggressive, dynamic combat, which is more fun, but it also more frustrating, and it drew many complaints. Losing a mission because it took one turn too many to blow up an objective just sucks. One of the most popular mods for XCOM 2 just outright disables the turn timer.

Instead of making you fail if you're too slow, Invisible Inc. slowly ramps up the difficulty. Every five turns, the alarm increases one level, making the mission slightly more difficult. At first it just inconveniences you (new cameras, better firewalls), but later it starts spawning in new guards with new patrols, all while teasing you with upgrade stations and corporate safes full of credits. It shifts your train of thought from "How do I complete the objective as fast as possible?" to "How far can I push my luck and still complete the objective?" which is infinitely more satisfying. It's up to you where you draw the line, which makes success more gratifying and failure more personal. Screw the "missed a 95% chance to hit" stuff. Your favorite agent died because you got too greedy.

It's a Klei game, so the graphics, music, and voice acting are all top notch. Story line is extremely basic and doesn't distract from letting you do what you want. Zero time-wasting cutscenes between missions (you'll get some story banter but you can skip right through it in a few seconds). No cringy or annoying NPCs. Runs great on your potato laptop.

My only complaint is that it's hard to tell where stuff is in rooms sometimes because walls/objects become invisible when you're facing them so you can see the room easier. It's great visually but results in a good bit of camera spinning in smaller areas to figure out where stuff is, buuuuut XCOM does the same thing so it's not a big deal.

Absolutely recommend.

An amazing game, indeed!

Just managed to beat the final level, and man, what a journey that was.

The General Gyst:
The game revolves around sneaking through levels with varying objectives.
Every mission sees your team spawn in a room, then find their way to that level's teleporter.
It is turn-based strategy, from an isometric perspective, and each of your agents starts with a special skill.
You deck your guys out with gear, bio-enhancements and four different skills.
Since you have a limited number of hours before embarking on the final mission, gear, skills and extra agents become strategic choices that make each run-though different from the other. Maps are proceduraly generated as well, which helps make every campaign fresh and challenging in its own way.
While the levels aren't too different from one another visually, the layout of the rooms and security personnel/equipment is where the variety really shines. You may think you've understood how hopping from cover to cover and drawing attention when necessary can define your success in a mission, until you come across a room which has two turrets you can hack to shoot down pursuers until they run dry on ammo.

In true cyber-punk fashion, the game takes place in two planes, the physical and the digital.
Throughout your missions, hacking is done via your AI, which can be used just as strategically as your agents. From disabling cameras to unlocking mid-level stores, everything is measured against the current alarm level (which gradually disrupts your plans the higher it gets, by adding guards or defence subsystems). 
The over-all threat of each mission is based on its difficulty level, which is at the heart of the risk/reward cycle you follow until reaching the final mission (harder missions early could help you gear-up stronger for the final mission, but could also straight-up whipe your team before you even get the chance to use your shiny, new sub-dermal invisibility implant). The game has quite a few settings for defining exactly how hard-core you feel your next run should be (enabling saving, re-tries and amount of different kinds of defences or impacts on alarm levels, etc.).

The final level took me quite a few tries, each of which devloped quite epically and uniquelly.
In fact, that final victory really did bring up a lot of the reasons I find the game so enjoyable.
I don't tend to write many reviews, but, honestly, this last mission really convinced me to try and let people know about Invisible Inc.

I had teleported into the most heavily guarded location I'd ever been to in that campaign, and my rag-tag group of cyber-punk agents had already broken through innumerable digital defences in order to allow our expert to access a specific comm-link. The guards hadn't exactly seen anyone rummaging about their military base just yet, but most already had a sunken feeling that something was off. When the first signs of fowl-play began pouring into their ear-pieces, my guys knew they had to divert attention from our hacker, and meticulously spotted one another jumping in and out of cover. We led them into parallel wild goose chases, purposefully triggering cameras, chucking smoke granades, and shooting paralizer darts in the most guerilla of fashions. Two of our agents lay dead on the ground, one of which had all of our remaining medical equipment. The others were quickly getting cornered by the guards that kept pouring in through various teleporters scattered around the map. However, hope was not lost, our hacker had carefully dashed his was to the final comm-link, and was typing and panting over its console. Every second counted, agent Dr. Xu had jumped behind a box with a needle to his chest, frigthened and in a cold sweat, but significantly less murdered. Agent Banks had just blown the fuses of her invisible cammo to flee from a group of guards in hot pursuit. She ducked behind one of the few pieces of cover in a cramped room, and had nowhere left to slip to as a dozen guards were closing in. As they basically breathed down her neck, Nika kicked down the door, only to become invisible herself, momentarily stunning and drawing the guards to investigate the ghostly disappearance they'd witnessed. My invisible couple, Banks and Nika, had just played their final hand, this was only a momentary feign, and they were still cornered and helpless. Suddenly, the final key was struck, the door had open, and our mission was finished. As the ending sequence was playing, I could imagine each the relief in each of my agents' faces, knowing all the preparation paid off. I won't go into anything specific, so as not to spoil any bit of story, but it truly felt like my guys beat the odds, and that a single extra turn could have meant certain tragedy.

[b] Gameplay: [/b] There are so many things to talk about the gameplay, so I will try to keep it as compact as possible. As a Turn-based game, you will use action points (AP) for your agents in order to finish your main objective. You also gain access to Incognita, an AI system that can hack devices in the facility using power (PWR) to help the agents stay hidden under camera surveillance or interact with other objects. However, AP and PWR are very limited each turns, so you need to calculate where the agents should go, or what devices you should hack. Stealth is a very big factor in this game, so sneaking around guards and drones, or using non lethal actions against them is your best option, rushing through a level without thinking will get things out of control real quick. You also need to pay attention to the Security Level, as each turn passes by, there will be more security measures applied, thus making the mission harder to complete. Try to execute each moves as safely and as efficient as possible, and you wont have much problems in the long run. After each missions, you can upgrade your agents with the credits you stole in the facility to make them faster, stronger, hack better, or steal more. The game has a very high replay value because of the procedural generation system for the map, so every missions will feel different each time you play, which makes the whole stealth aspect of the game more meaningful. In short, the gameplay of Invisible, Inc. is challenging but high rewarding if you know what you're doing, and you will spend countless hours with it if you're experienced enough.

[b] Sound: [/b] Solid voice acting, nothing bad to say at all. The soundtracks on the other hand are very good and fit in with the overall theme. You can feel the tension, the stealthiness, and even a bit of cyberpunk every time you listen to them in the background while doing a mission. Perfect soundtracks for this game I must say.

[b] The DLCs: [/b] I recommend you buy the Contingency Plan DLC to play along with the main game, it adds more agents, weapons, enemy types, and an extended campaign if you want to get more out of the main story. Totally worth it in my book.

[b] The Negatives: [/b] The biggest problem I have with this game weirdly enough is actually its gameplay. As fun and engaging the gameplay is, it has also caused so much stress and anxiety to me. If you see the nearly 36 hours of game time that I spent on this game, you're probably thinking I have played through this 2 or 3 times already, but weirdly enough that was the total time for my first playthrough only. It took me too much time thinking about each moves I was about to make, and I freaked out when I did something wrong or clicked the wrong buttons, which happened quite a lot. I know it doesn't 100% count as a negative, but I want to put it out there so if you're one of the people who wants to do everything right the first time like me, this game might causes you some health issues lol.

[b] Final Verdict: [/b] Invisible, Inc. is the prime example of how to do a great Turn-based Stealth game, one that I will be more than happy to go back and spend most of my free time on it in the future. Definitely play this game if you're a fan of the genre. Easily a 9/10 for me.

59013236.review:
Invisible Inc. is a stealth based isometric turn based strategy game. There have been times I've played other strategy games and was disappointed with the options available other than “kill them all in as few turns as possible because they will only attempt to kill you.” This game scratches that itch, somewhat.

It's not to say the game is bad. It really isn't. But it's also not amazing. The UI seems a bit cluttered, which is strange because there isn't much going on in the UI. My main gripe is that the game wants you to play claustrophobicly close to the characters. But with large or tall levels scrolling with the keyboard or mouse feels unresponsive. This issue is more apparent with hostile movements being globally represented on the map with subtle sound wave indicators. The game doesn't ever take control of your camera, so if you encountered 5 guards 6 rooms down hunting you, the movement hints will be often off screen. 

Another big issue with the UI is that it also struggles with pacing. I'm either at the end game or firmly in the mid game at the time of writing. And the number of intractable objects in the level is getting quite high. I was quite frustrated when I had a mission that required I split my party to interact with two objects on the same turn. Only to move one before I had clicked the button to interact. This is frustrating because it's very easy for me to overlook. Because the interaction bar pops up only on the prop, inline with other default actions. This again can simply appear off screen based on your camera positioning.

Despite these faults, the game does an excellent job at selling the stealth angle! Doors can be opened and closed to manipulate enemy AI, leading them through empty rooms and buying your team time. You can peak through even locked doors and around corners to plan your approach. The game is also very friendly to easily frustrated players like myself. It offers an arguably game breakingly powerful do-over mechanic. Depending on the difficulty you can have quite a few, and I often go the entire level without even knowing I had it. The game's RNG determinations are made at the level generation, so if left to act without player interference. The enemy AI will always behave as it would have before the do-over, part of why the mechanic is powerful.

Most important to the game's core gameplay loop, is both a short term and long term resource scarcity mechanic. In every level you have two main means of generating power for the AI to hack discovered props, such as doors, sentries, safes, and vendors. In the short term, each levels starts you with some power. In spite of the thumbs down I must say Invisible Inc. is not a bad game. The problem was, perhaps, my expectations.

Coming from the Harebrained Shadowrun games I was expecting something somewhat similar, and what you get here may look like that at first sight but it only takes one or two missions to realize that's really not the case.

First and foremost, the game is built around replayability. An entire campaign took me about 6 hours, granted that was on the beginner mode difficulty. You are meant to replay it several times and on harder difficulties just so you can challenge yourself but it honestly doesn't interest me in the least.

There's little to no character development for your agents (I mean this, I wouldn't be surprised if they have less than 5 lines of dialogue each and it's only on mission start to make some witty remark like "lets do this so I can go drink"). There are only two cinematics (first and last mission) and the story being told here is bare bones and can't be compared to any other similar title without outright saying it's bad.

Gameplay is more like XCOM than Shadowrun. Centered around a handful (maybe two handfuls) of short missions without much influence in the story itself. You just go around invading corporate installations so you can get money and items to upgrade your agents. It puzzles me that they decided to make the leveling up and gear acquisition dependent of the same resource. You are forced to choose between buying better items or upgrading your character's stats. Those mechanics should have been separate. It's also mind boggling why you'd need to spend money on "fabricators" or other "kiosks"you hack during missions in order for them to build/program your stuff. I mean, what's the point of fighting the Big Bad Corporations if you are still going to pay them for things? It leads to ridiculous situations where you may take a mission specifically meant for you to "acquire" gear from a special fabricator kiosk just for you to get there and realize you can't buy without gimping your character progression (if you can afford anything at all).

Inventory management is also a complete pain, with most characters only being able to carry 4 or 5 items (depends on your stats, which I remind you require money to upgrade) regardless of their type. The problem here is that all items occupy the same slots, so if you carry a gun or a keycard, both "weigh" the same and encumber your character in the same manner if you go over capacity. This is increasingly bothersome when you consider melee weapons have long cooldowns (meaning you can only use them every 3 or so turns at best) and ranged ones come with extremely limited ammo (2 bullets? really? you are going to raid a megacorp installation with 2 bullets?). Sure, you can bring along "weapon recharge items", which are consumable and occupy one of your precious and limited slots. There's the problem of limited storage as well, as you can only keep 4 or 5 items saved at your "base" between runs. By the way "your base" is the mission selection screen, there's no actual hub.

Overall, I felt rushed through the entire game. You go from mission to mission with the only objective of getting credits so you can buy gear or upgrade stats. Sure, you could say that's pretty much any game, but there's really nothing behind that requirement motivating you to "get gud". Without a story or characters backing up all that prodding, I think I would have quit without finishing even one campaign if it had lasted much longer. Even on the last mission the main strategy was "sitting" on top of downed enemies so they wouldn't get up again while one or two characters did all the heavy lifting.

Now, without spoilers, I'll say that I found the ending disappointing. It's actually quite remarkable that with so little story telling they managed to cramp so much foreshadowing during the last mission alone that it made the outcome extremely predictable. The sad part is that it could have worked out had it been just the first arc of the story. It left me feeling like I had played a demo and not a full game.

So well, in the end I can't recommend Invisible Inc to the overall public. Specially if you are looking for something Shadowrun-ish or X-COM like. It has none of the story and character of the first and none of the deep tactical gameplay of the latter. It's "complex" mechanics are, as I've mentioned, poorly thought out and cumbersome instead of entertaining.

If, however, every complaint I made sounds totally fine to you (which is completely possible), then you may actually enjoy Invisible Inc for what is and you might want to give it a shot.

It's not a bad game. It's just not for me.

An incredible stealth tactical game that has you infiltrate facilities as a group of cyberpunk rebels who get one-shot in any direct confrontation. It's part [i]XCOM[/i], part [i]Into the Breach:[/i] there's no randomness in numbers, and you can get all the information you need (like guard routes). However, to spy on them efficiently, you need to take risks and scout ahead... which is dangerous.

The game is balanced perfectly. The alarm is constantly rising, pressuring you out of overly cautious playstyle, but get too cocky—and you get wiped. Unlike [i]XCOM[/i], you can't really clear the level: you stun enemies instead of killing them, and if you dawdle, they'll come to and set after you from behind. The tension becomes very real, very quickly.

The visuals are clear and memorable, the characters likeable, and the music pleasant. The only downsides I can think of is that the rules of vision become complicated sometimes (it might be hard to figure out in a crowded room if your hiding place will fall into a guard's field of vision as they move); and also that your success heavily depends on the random level generation: if the two objectives of the last mission are in two different ends of the map, you'll be heavily disadvantaged compared to someone who gets them close.

Then again, the latter is balanced by how short the campaign is. If you fail—which you will—you won't feel like you've lost a ton of progress, and starting over doesn't feel like a chore.

All in all, a great tactical game for anyone who loves to think on the grid and plan their every step. (Also, Internationale + Parasite = OP.)

54025156.review:
An interesting idea that I wanted to really love: the alarm is always rising and you have to maintain your stealth in this turn-based grid tactics game. It looks beautiful and there are a lot of cool toys. Was fun for a playthrough before Contingency Plan, was fun for a playthrough after Contingency Plan, especially when I figured out how to kite guards. However, the poor communication of audio range, general fiddliness, and lack of content variety got me bored pretty quickly.

The draw of most roguelikes is that you're mitigating randomness by putting together a strategy on the fly with whatever you find. Although Invisible Inc. does have a lot of random stuff going on, a dominant playstyle emerges: every agent should have a cloak, a neural disrupter, and a stim: all other items are excessively situational. Later on you should have paralyzers and AP as well. Your designated paperweight agent should be dragging a KOed guard above another KOed guard somewhere out-of-sight, so that you can keep two knocked out guards out of the rotation indefinitely. PWR is disabled cameras and unlocked safes, so have some way of generating a lot. You should avoid guards and get as far into the facility as you can before you can't avoid knocking more guards out, at which point you're a few turns away from escaping and cut bait. 

Within this playstyle (which, by the way, doesn't really change when you're playing endless), you're solving the same puzzle over and over again: how do I get across this room without alerting a guard? And figuring out line of sight for guards in motion is, while super deterministic, annoying as heck. 

The game punishes you severely for deviating from The One True Playstyle. Don't kill people -- you'll raise the alarm. Don't bust daemons unless you know what they are or have to -- you'll screw yourself over. Don't hack the robots unless you have to -- it'll alert them. Don't use wacky consumables: they waste space and your inventory slots are precious. Creativity is limited to kiting guards around to let other people deeper into the facility, which was entertaining for about an hour -- and I think that's the main problem. When it comes to risk-reward in this game, there's no incentive to do anything remotely interesting: by doing so, you're taking on unnecessary risk, fighting the game every step of the way. And the core loop just isn't interesting enough to justify more than a couple playthroughs of its tight but sterile mechanics.

Fantastic game - plays a lot like a roguelike.  You start with two characters with preset starting equipment and pick from random missions with randomly generated levels.  I really like how everything is predictable (literally, actually, you can spend an action point to predict a guards movement if you can see him).  No random chance to hit, random damage, or any of that - plus you can tell exactly what an action will do before you do it.  The only thing random is the map generation - (well, that and some passive boosts you can get).  You never know where the objective will be or where the exit will be when you start a level.  What makes the game difficult is that you're outnumbered, outgunned, enemies will start spawning/respawning if you're taking too long or if you're triggering alarms, and knocking out guards can cost you, since they wake back up and start panicking - killing them is often expensive and will trip alarms if you don't hack their heart monitors as well.  You constantly need to strike the right balance between moving quickly and cautiously, which makes the game tense.

That being said, it's tense but fair, and you can always just play on a lower difficulty if you find it too tense or too difficult.  Playing your first game on the easiest difficulty is strongly advised, since the mechanics are very complex and you often have to take advantage of every possible opportunity that the game's features give you, if you're playing on normal.

(All that being said, it's pretty ridiculous that you can hide behind a standing lamp or a chair in the middle of the room and not get seen by a passing guard)

TL;DR  It's a great tactical, turn-based stealth game that doesn't have the built-in frustration of thing like random chance to hit or random damage.

52292201.review:
This game oozes style from every pore. The art direction gives every environment a sleek, beautiful minimalism. The characters are sharp and angular, each expressing a different flavour of neo-noir [i] coolness [/i]. Hell, even the title: Invisible, Inc. - is unique and embodies its own special style. The aesthetic is fantastic.
But the aesthetic of a game doesn't matter nearly so much as its gameplay. Invisible's gameplay can best be described as XCOM 2, but with tactical stealth instead of tactical combat.
In each run, you move a vehicle around a wireframe map, jumping from mission to mission. Each mission offers a different objective and a different reward, preparing you for the game's final gauntlet. Along the way, your agents gain new gadgets and cyber-augments to add a little flavour to every run.
But what about that gameplay? Turn-based stealth? Have you ever played a turn based stealth game? Chances are, no. Does it work?
Surprisingly, yes. Missions begin almost puzzle-like, with you trying to discover the safest path from point A to B, weaving your agents between the vision cones of unaware security guards. Despite the thinness of said cones, and the player's ability to control security cameras to keep tabs on enemies, There's never the feeling of being in total control, thanks to some clever information control, hiding crucial information from the player that keeps them guessing.
The pressure is kept up by the alarm meter, forcing you to always keep your finger on the pulse. As it ticks up, more reinforcements are spawned and the system begins detecting the positions of your agents. There's never a game over when it gets too high, but the enemies never stop, and on a long enough timescale the odds of survival always drop to zero. The clock forces you to play in a more engaging way. As it ticks up and the mission gets longer, you start taking risks - crossing more ground in a single turn, toeing the very edge of enemy vision cones, hacking into equipment even though doing so will spawn virus programs with unknown effects.
The game isn't a perfect puzzle anymore, but an exercise of risk-taking and damage control. The game is most tense when you end your turn with an agent in the open, holding your breath and hoping that a guard doesn't walk out from any of those unscouted doors and spot them in the middle of the room. You're never in control, and the clock is always ticking. Things will go wrong, but you should embrace that - narrow escapes are some of the game's best moments.

The game is damaged by one small mechanic. During each run, one of the game's mission types has you breaking into a holding cell to rescure another agent. If you get them out, they'll join your crew, and you'll have three pairs of hands to work with intead of two. This sounds cool, but in practice hurts the balance of the mechanics quite a lot. An extra agent is an extremely powerful buff. That's 50% more scouting, 50% more looting, and 50% more enemy takedowns every turn. Getting an agent early is extremely helpful for your run - but if you aren't lucky enough to have that mission type spawn early on, your run is going to be significantly more difficult, making an otherwise pretty fair game fairly reliant on RNG. The game's action economy also falls apart completely the more agents you add. With four agents, the maps become far too claustrophobic for them all to have a use: it's rare to be exploring four different rooms at once, and if you need to kill four guards in a single turn, that mission has probably gone so deep to hell that no amount of agents will pull it back out.
Instead,  while the other agents do the real work, one is usually assigned to 'corpse duty', moving back and forth to transport unconscious bodies to out-of-reach locations, occasionally re-stunning them to prevent them waking up. Micromanaging an agent on corpse duty is one of the most repetitive and least engaging things in the game.

Overall, however, the extra agent problem doesn't destroy the experience unless you're really looking for it to.
Onto other things: The story, like most cyberpunk plots, is  cut-down and reassembled from Neuromancer - godlike AI, meddling corporations, etc. It's extremely simple, but it's told well, and it accomplishes what it intended, so it's a pass in my books.
The game is less encouraging of creative playstyles as it could be, and it does kind of funnel you into a certain pattern, but as that pattern is inherently fun to engage with, I had (and hopefully will continue to have) plenty of fun with it over my playtime. Invisible, Inc is a wonderfully stylish breath of fresh air in both the roguelike and stealth genres, delivering a memorable experience with a focused vision and very little unnecessary fat.

Invisible, Inc. checked many of my favorite boxes: stealth, turn-based strategy, isometric view, and colorful art style. Not only that but the studio, Klei Entertainment, created possibly the best 2D stealth game I've ever played, "Mark of the Ninja" (2012). So I purchased Invisible, Inc. on sale and sunk about 8 hours into it. The game does a fairlly good introduction tutorial of the game's rules and navigation. But as you get deeper into the world, you'll soon see the cracks in the design. This game is too unforgiving and the fun depletes the more you progress.

Starting with the positives, this game looks and feels right. The unique art style is similar to other Klei Entertainment titles. There is the thrill of completing a stage just in the nick of time. Looting the entire stage of all its treasure is particularly satisfying since it is quite difficult to do in later stages. The core concept is simple and well thought out. It's the execution that leaves me wanting.

The procedurally generated levels don't make much sense. I feel like the developers wanted to implement this in order to have an infinite amount of replayability for the player, but sometimes the stages will drastically differ in fairness. One stage I encountered had the target and the escape elevator side by side, creating a very simple stage to complete. While another stage generated was a labyrinth of doors that lead to rooms the size of tiny closets. Stages like these feel ridiculous and unfair. It doesn't help that doors and walls can sometimes get muddled together, such that enemy line of sight is unclear. I would have preferred a set of levels designed by the developer and perhaps a game level editor that players could share amongst themselves.

The game difficulty and other variables can be toggled at the beginning of the game. This is somewhat strange at first but after the first play-through you'll understand it. The one major thing I don't like about the difficulty is that every move you make in the game is a penalty. The enemy knows that you've broken into the base and the security levels increase each turn. Why is it designed this way? Isn't this supposed to be a stealth game? The title of game is "Invisible, Inc.". I know that the game wants to create some sort of tension, but it is highly unlikely that you can complete a level without physically encountering an enemy.

There's also a hacking element in the game. But when you hack there is a high chance that you will trigger some kind of alarm or penalty. I'd be okay with this if the game could show the percentage of risk involved, or some kind of mini game; however, it's all up to luck and no skill is involved. A missed opportunity. The loot isn't that good either. You'll constantly have to find energy, credits, and keycards, yet it never feels pleasurable once you find it. You can augment your characters in certain stages but it never quite feels rewarding or cool. More like a chore to be honest.

I'd only recommend Invisible, Inc. if you can find it on a deep sale. There are some good ideas and mechanics. It's like a pretty date that you soon realize has no depth or interest. Good thing Mark of the Ninja still exists. Play that instead.

50729580.review:
Fictionally, Invisible Inc. is about a group of remaining spies from a watchdog organization after a crippling raid on their headquarters struggling to survive against the more brutal organizations. Mechanically, Invisible Inc is a turn-based stealth strategy game (often compared to X-COM) that has you using a collection of well-crafted mechanics to solve problems posed by procedurally generated maps.

These maps have main objectives based on the mission type and additional side objectives. Although only exiting is required to finish the mission, you will want to get the most out of every mission. So you must choose your missions' type based on your team's current strengths and weaknesses to prepare your team before the final mission.

Where Invisible Inc. struggles is in communicating its mechanics, the game's tutorial only teaches the bare minimum toolset. This is perhaps countered by the beginner difficulty, as it gives you ways to rewind turns and redo missions. Although this more hands-off approach might work in the long-term, it can make the player feel cheated when faced with a setback because of a mechanic the game never directly taught the player, or even worse, if the player never learns these systems, feel defeated.

Despite this, if you have some patience to learn the finer details of the game, you'll be well rewarded. Once you have the full toolset, you'll be able to handle practically anything the game throws at you. Even seemingly impossible situations provided some good thought is put in, can be overcome. And It's getting out of these desperate scrapes, even if barely, that is so rewarding about playing and mastering this game.
~ Recommended

RNG will make or break your playthrough, but I've never had so much fun restarting a campaign over and over again. 

There's good and bad on both sides of it, but if players needed to know any one thing before buying, it's that the game suffers from a side-pan glitch that makes the game unplayable until your cpu is restarted (sometimes more than once). That this issue reoccurs at random is annoying;  that this has persisted since the game's launch is nothing short of frustrating. According to Steam forums, Klei has only suggested that it may be your mouse (it's not), and seeing that those date back to 2015, it's clear they mean to leave the game in this state.

Obviously, I've recommended the title, so hear me out:
- The game is, overall, really well balanced, rewarding careful strategy in a way that is satisfying to both beginner and experienced gamers.
- There are countless different combinations of starting load-outs that work towards a winning strategy.
- And it's not bad to lose: even a failed campaign yields EXP towards new agents and programs.
- Splinter Cell meets X-Com: a very unique take on the stealth genre.

Now for the bad:
- I've already mentioned the heavy RNG aspect, which will spawn some pretty unfortunate circumstances that only the luckiest and most prepared players will get through without calling the mission a bust and rushing for the exit. 
 - Not to mention the side-pan glitch (the screen locks in a downward scroll like your mouse fell off the desk). A simple restart usually does the trick, but leaving such a huge issue to come and go at random is less than satisfying.
- It amazes me how a game with such a small file size runs so poorly on start-up. Even simple movement animation will lag and stumble for the first ten minutes or so of the game, and I've never once seen a smooth KD animation.

All that being said, there really is no other game like it, and it's a welcome addition to my library.

It's kind of like a 2D XCOM, only with a focus on Stealth instead of combat. You have a small team of up to 4 agents, each with different starting gear and abilities, and complete missions in each level. You have an alarm level which represents the enemy's awareness of you, normally it goes up by 1 each turn although you can tweak that if you like. The higher the alarm level the harder the enemies get and the more units they pull to stop you. 

Combat is deadly when you do it, because your agents die in one hit if they are spotted. When spotted you have a chance to immediately move the agent into adjacent cover or kill the enemy that spotted you, if you move the agent in the open after they've been spotted, they get shot and bleed out. 

The best thing about it though is you can hack cameras and stuff to get a layout and learn guard patrols, so you can plan out your approach and get intel on what lies ahead before you move there, or keep an eye on the whole map to ensure  you have an escape route planned. 

Essentially Invisible Inc. is like a 2D XCOM game, only you fight corporations instead of aliens, and the focus here is stealth, not combat, don't go in guns blazing or you'll have a bad time.

After successfully completing the storyline on my third save (1 bugged out in tutorial, 2nd I goofed) I feel I can properly say: this is a must have for anyone a fan of turn based stealth puzzle games.

There is no probability - you either will be able to knock out a guard, or you won't because his armor is too strong. If you've made a mistake, it will genuinely feel like you're fault, whether you miscalculated or didn't have enough preparations. As such, you won't go in to take down a guard to raid a vault, only to have yourself to blame if you increase the alarm, or walk in front of another camera.

Mind you, probability does not mean the same thing as unexpected curve balls: you can sometimes go a while without finding a significant weapon, or you'll find nothing but the best in your first few missions. Sometimes your objective will be on the other side of the map as the escape transport, or they could be right next to eachother.

The game only leaves randomness to two elements: the layout of a level, and the items found within a level. The rest is more or less up to you: the choice of going after weapons, cash, programs, hostage rescue or general supply runs. Do you stealth a mission, or do you have the weapons to knock out or kill every guard in sight?

Most of the time if I found myself in a bad situation, I found myself to blame and only myself, and that's a good thing. Strategy games where a highly random factor that can screw over the best of runs are frustrating, and Klei has NOT made one of those. Amazing graphics, good music, and a simple interface make it a very good running and fun to play game.

47189895.review:
Conversation at the Klei water cooler:

Employee #1: So, "Mark of the Ninja" was a huge hit. Really didn't see that coming.

Employee #2: Ha ha; I see what you did there, #1. Since it seems like we just revolutionized platformers by integrating stealth, what's next on our genre-transformation list?

Employee #1: Great question, #2. I'll chew on that while I'm rocking some "X-Com."

Both employees stare at each other, then drop their cups and dash madly back to their desks. 

Seriously, though. What is it with Klei's ability to make an utterly brilliant game by offering formula of 'mash-up genre x + stealth?' It's like fusion food, but 100% good instead of just '50% different.' As with "Mark of the Ninja," "Invisible, Inc." is light on overall story but heavy on theme and atmosphere. Where "Mark" really makes the player feel like a ninja navigating a pseudo-futurisitic corporate world, "Invisible" instantly immerses the player in the role of a remote Operator for a group of infiltration experts in it's dystopian cyberpunk world. This engrossing experience isn't limited to the visuals and text, either: sound effects and music again play a critical role. Klei's ability to build compelling worlds, on every level (pun intended), rivals it's ability to make interesting, layered, enjoyable game play.

On the subject of game play, several reviewers have pointed out the difficulty of "Invisible, Inc." While there is some merit to those observations, they are mostly exaggerated. Yes, the game has a learning curve and the challenge scaling is rather steep between difficulties. Turn-based tactical and stealth games both require the player to plan ahead while leaving room to adjust, but in different ways for each style of game. Contrary to popular belief, however, those skills don't overlap quite as much as you might think. It will take time to figure out how to blend them together effectively. It's not "Dark Souls" or "Dead Cell" difficult, but it is a rogue-like with all the commensurate challenges and frustrations that genre contains. For example, here's a rough breakdown of my play time through the first ~50 hours (note: all modes were run with the "Contingency Plan" DLC active):

-Beginner Campaign completed successfully: ~14 hours. Yes, I'm slow. This included one mission replay during day 4 (where I was beaten quite soundly despite having a full team and 5 rewinds). Success on Day 7 was still messy. Started with Internationale + Decker. 
-Experienced Campaign completed successfully): ~30 hours. I mentioned I'm slow, right? Wasn't kidding. This included half a dozen failed attempts, one of which reached Day 4 (washed out on a different mission than in my Beginner playthrough). Final success on Day 7 was pretty clean. Finally figured out that I should experiment with different starting agents and programs. Who knew? For the record, Banks + Prism running with Fusion and Lockpick v 1.0 made for pretty smooth sailing.
-Endless: ~4 hours. Two attempts, one of which went to Day 3 before I lost my team. Currently trying again with the 'proven' duo of Banks + Prism.

While I'm a something of a novice in the turn-based tactics department, I am no stranger to stealth games. Because of that, I exptected to encounter success in reasonably short order. But before I could bask in victory, I had to fail. Repeatedly. I had to make mistakes. Many mistakes. And learn from them. Sometimes it took a while, but when I finally got the lesson through my thick skull, I was a better player for it. And getting good enough to finally surmount the wall I had been banging my head against was unbelievably gratifying. Exhilarating, really.

8/10, two thumbs up. If you dig turn based tactics or stealth games, check out "Invisible, Inc." Learning curve aside, it's a whole lot of fun for those willing to invest the time.

45816354.review:
[h1] Introducción [/h1]
Los niveles de alarmas se incrementan, no tienes munición y usarla solo incrementaría la vigilancia, el tiempo de reutilización de tus armas eléctricas es demasiado alto y te han hackeado. ¿La idea era infiltrarse, robar dinero, información y mejoras? Al final, has perdido todo tu grupo y, aunque ganaste experiencia, toca volver a reiniciar el reloj para enfrentarse nuevamente a las mega-corporaciones que dominan el mundo. Esto es Invisible Inc, juego creado por la mega-corporación Klei Entertaiment, el cual fue finalista en el Independent Games Festival bajo la categoría de «Excelencia en diseño». Es el primer turn-based que desarrolla Klei y se notan los ecos provenientes de Xcom, pero mantiene su originalidad respecto a las mecánicas.

[h1] Historia: 8/10 [/h1]
En el 2074, las mega-corporaciones han tomado el poder global. Invisible Inc. es una agencia de espías que, al principio, brindaba sus servicios a estas corporaciones: sus espías se infiltraban y robaban información con ayuda de una inteligencia artificial llamada Incognita. Al iniciar la partida vemos que Invisible Inc. es atacada por las fuerzas de la corporación y tienen que huir. Lastimosamente, huir conlleva sus consecuencias: sólo logran escapar dos agentes, Monst3r y la líder de la agencia, quien se llevó consigo a Incognita. Sin embargo, Incognita sólo puede sobrevivir en un sistema informático especialmente potente y, si no está conectada, sólo sobrevivirá 72 horas. [spoiler] El objetivo es prepararse durante 72 horas para lograr el objetivo final: infiltrarse en la sede del enemigo donde podrían tener un sistema que soporte a Incognita. Al final, cuando logran integrar a incógnita al sistema operativo, ella desobedece a la líder y decide acabar con todas las megacorporaciones usando un satélite equipado con armamento láser... en el proceso, mueren cientos de personas. 
Aunque la historia es emocionante y solo tener cuatro misiones previas a la final es desafiante, el final es muy predecible. ¿Cuándo no se ha visto que las inteligencias artificiales se salen de las manos de sus creadores? Por esa razón, no la considero muy original. [/spoiler]

[h1] Mecánicas 10/10 [/h1]
Desde una vista isométrica o perspectiva 3/4, tienes que manejar la facción espía durante las expediciones preparatorias para la misión final, en las cuales debes ganar experiencia, robar equipamiento, rescatar camaradas, conseguir armas y dinero. Como ya se dijo, este juego implementa la estrategia por turnos al mejor estilo de Xcom, pero tiene mecánicas originales que permiten una experiencia de juego altamente satisfactoria: el sistema de alarma, la perspectiva táctica (la cual debería ser implementada en Xcom para evitar malas pasadas con las superficies) y, especialmente, el sistema de ayuda que brinda Incognita. Este sistema es especialmente útil porque permite hackear cámaras, cajas fuertes, drones, etcétera... además, puedes equiparla para distraer al enemigo. 
Una vez sumas todos estos elementos e incluyes la gran cantidad de enemigos con diferentes niveles de armadura, los molestos malware que intentan detener a Incognita y la perdida permanente de tus miembros (no necesariamente mueren, pero pierdes todo lo que hayas invertido en ellos) en caso de abandono o si los atrapan, entonces obtienes un juego sumamente satisfactorio y con una escala de dificultad elevada porque morirás mucho —demasiado en mi caso—. Sin embargo, morir no es del todo malo porque sirve para desbloquear personajes y gadges para Incognita, los cuales serán muy útiles.

[h1] Apartado audiovisual 8/10 [/h1]
El diseño de personajes es excelente, los escenarios están muy bien logradas y la perspectiva 3/4 no presenta dificultades. En las horas de juego, me he llegado a encariñar con ciertos personajes por sus talentos y su diseño, las mujeres de este juego son de lo mejor que hay (tanto a nivel de equipamiento, como de diseño). Sin embargo, la banda sonora no es nada del otro mundo. Más explícitamente creo que la banda sonora acompaña bien el juego, pero podrían hacer algo distinto. Es un cliché usar esos temas repetitivos y excesivamente atmosféricos para los turn-based. 

[h1] Puntuación final: 8.5/10 [/h1]

45049069.review:
Interesting concept hampered by inconsistent difficulty. 

I played this game with the Contingency DLC on at all times.

Overview
Invisible Inc is a turn based strategy game in which the player uses a squad of agents, and their gear with the help of a Computer named Incognita to infiltrate corporations for credits, programs, and loot. The levels are randomly generated as you must kill or sneak passed guards, hack through firewalls, and escape as the ever increasing alarm levels bring in more guards.

Mechanics
Your team teleports into a level. You are to achieve and objective (though that's sometimes optional) and then find the exit teleporter and leave. Levels are played out on a grid, and each unit can only make so many actions a turn. After the player completes all of their movements and hacks the AI takes its turn. Agents can move, use an attack action, use an item, peek through doors, or collect power for Incognito. Incognito uses an alternative AI and provides power for herself as well as various programs used to break mainframes or in other ways aid your team. Agents have augments which grant passive powers as well as slots for items they can bring with them into the level. Between missions, players can upgrade agents, sell some items (occasionally buy 1) and then select missions from a handful presented by the game.

Ideally, a player should be able to understand all the tools they game presents, make favorable decisions (which are to be rewarded) and carefully upgrade their team to win the game. However, Invisible Inc isn't that clear cut. Some items descriptions are poor or non-existent. Flash grenade, for example, simply gives the option to be dropped. What you need to do (had to look up in google) is select the grenade then select the tile you want to throw it at. I get not explaining tactics or strategy but not explain simple mechanics? It is frustrating just to figure out how enemy vision works, which is not something you want in a stealth game. It actually periodically turns off during movements which is why you can stand right next to some guards, they turn and look right at you, but don't "see" you. In endless mode the game introduces 3 new mechanics, at once, when a player reaches a certain day. That's pretty ridiculous to have players make their way through expert difficulty for time that could be 5+ hours just to spring new concepts on them without warning.

The Gameplay
The real issue is the RNG. Items, missions, rewards, layouts, everything is random (outside of a few set story missions and what the player chooses to start the game with). While this RNG is to enhance replayability, it causes a lot of problems in difficulty spikes/plunges. There were times on expert I could zip through the entire missions with no real challenge or have a run with absurd items but then some missions become so ridiculously hard it feels impossible to navigate through the level at all. Side objectives are simply impossible 95% of the time on higher difficulties. I mean, having an 1 of your 2 available agents sitting idol for 7 turns just isn't viable. Worse, even some of the main missions feel impossible. This can lead to a negative feedback loop of falling too far behind.

The key aspect of the game is interacting with enemy NPCs guards attempt to stop the player. There is a solid variety of enemies for players to navigate through. They can be killed, which for some reason incurs a clean up cost (no idea how they send the bill to the player), KO them, or slip passed by nothing their movement pattern or by using a distraction. Using a distraction such as running or opening a door is the most rewarding part of the gameplay. However there are problems. Guard movement in not guaranteed. While most guards move from a point A to point B, this can be interrupted by the movement of another NPC thus throwing out a players ability to predict movement. Furthermore, even if you take reasonable precautions, such as entering a room incover with overwatch, it is possible for 2 npcs to walk the same path and put you into a bad position. 

Mistakes are either ignored (lucked out running in blind) or severely punished. One single tile can make the difference from a clean escape to your entire team being wiped out. Typically the later happens when there are multiple guards which can pour into the area. While the player can escape from some improbable odds, It's still very much sink or swim. It to often feels that the player wins because they didn't get bad rng versus the feeling of playing well. I assume that's why the game has rewinds to reset turns. While a nice way to get a player to learn (because mechanics are poorly explained) but it also is like an ex machina for weak game design. Contingency actually makes the problem worse by extending the campaign for even more days, almost doubling the length of time for a player to get a clear and thus doubling the chances of a playing slipping up that one time that just ends a 4-6+ hour run.

Story
There really isn't much of a narrative which is a shame. There are some talking heads between missions and unskippable repeatable banter at the beginning of missions but that's it. You can get back stories for the agents, but that requires doing one of the harder side missions to get a single one. in 85 hours of gameplay I unlocked 1.

Miscellaneous 
I like the visuals. They do provide a lot of ways to work the UI with rotating the camera, lowering the walls, having an alt view to highlight doors and such, but when multiple people are in a room, all the overlaying can make knowing what you are interacting with difficult.

Overall
There were times I enjoyed the game and the challenge it presented, but it simply became to frustrating losing hours of progress on a single mistake that felt very reasonable at the time. To often I thought I got out of a situation by pure chance versus good game play and the ebb and flow of the difficulty provides an uneven gaming experience. Perhaps with more experience I would have some of the finer nuances of the game down to increase consistency, but the game just doesn't engage me enough to try.

First off, what i love about this game is, that the RNG factor is kept to a minimum. A missed sniper shot for example in XCOM can cost you the life of a unit and from there everything can go south. In Invisible Inc. this is completely different. Weapons have no miss rate, but everything is based on cooldowns and tight on resources, like limited ammo, to keep the game challenging. But since Invisible Inc. is heavily focused on stealth, you will actually get punished, if you extensively use weapons to progress in the missions. Guards will leave their patrol path once you knocked them down for a few rounds and then they will start looking for your agents. You will also get punished for killing guards at the end of the mission by paying a "clean up" fee. Since money is always tight, you actually will think twice, if it's really necessary, to snipe that guard down.

The game design is absolute brilliant when it comes to the implemented alarm system. The longer you stay in a mission, the higher the alarm goes up, the tougher it gets to escape. High risk = high reward. "Should i stay a bit longer to loot that juicy safe for money, or should i escape with the elevator, to avoid any further trouble with the guards, that are hunting me down?"

Since the missions are always randomly generated, the replayability is endless. Coupled with the high amount of available agents, that have individual abilities, you will not get bored for a long time. The only thing that can get frustrating is not getting good items (hello RNG) for future missions. Some items have a huge impact, on how you advance in later missions. An early found ECON chip cuts down the difficulty in half for further missions, since you can gather so much faster money from the missions. Having more money early available, means you can improve the stats of the agents much quicker, buy more items, which leads to more money generating and increases the probability, that you will succeed in future missions.

All in all this game is a very well crafted gem. If you like turn-based strategy games, you should add this game 100% to your collection.

Invisible Inc. is one of my all time favorite games.  It’s kind of a cross between XCOM and Mission Impossible.  The game is turn based with limited action points per turn.  After six turns, the game moves to the next round.  This involves incrementing the security level which increases the pressure on your team.  You begin with two agents, but can grow up to a four member operation.  Each agent has “a particular set of skills” that you must integrate as part of the team’s toolkit.  Every mission involves your team getting into a secure location, completing an objective, and escaping.  The game is very unforgiving, but the mechanics let you see where your enemies are going, where they’re looking, and lots of tools and abilities to distract or disable them.  Along with your agents, you have access to a software system that allows you to hack and disable cameras, take over security systems, and unlock safes.

As you can see, the game has a cartoonish look, but a serious tone.  The art style has a lot of character and was what originally drew me to this game.  The music does a great job creating the atmosphere while you’re on a mission.  There are also the little things, like hearing the footsteps of a guard on the other side of a door, which gives a nice touch to the game.  The voice acting is also very well done.

The controls are simple and easy to use.  You can rotate your view if you are trying to see things from a different angle.  I really liked how there’s a different overlay for the device hacking.  The view can quickly be swapped back and forth, so to not disrupt your planning.

The game begins with your team’s HQ getting raided.  A few operatives escape and now they must figure out who is behind this.  Between missions, there’ll be some short banter with the boss of what’s going on and what decision you’ll have to make next.  The story does have an ending, however if you really like playing game, there is an endless mode that lets you keep playing past where the story would stop you.

Even if you can’t beat the game on the first try, you’re efforts are not wasted.  You get scored on how well you did for the playthrough, earning points.  Points eventually hit milestones unlocking new available starting agents and hacking skills.  These unlock might give you the tools you need/want to accommodate your playstyle or allow you to play the game in a different way.  Along with the unlocks letting you change the starting conditions, there are also several configurable options to change the overall game as well.  Settings such as number of guards, alarm triggering conditions, amount of money available to steal, as well as an iron man mode.

Overall, this game exceeded my expectations.  I was very impressed how much fun and addicting this game can be.  I think lots of people would enjoy this game and for its current price, it’s a must play.

Also, the DLC is very good as well and adds some new interesting features.  I wish one day this game gets a sequel.

Klei Entertainment’s [i]Mark of the Ninja[/i] is my favourite all-time stealth game because the user interface makes it very easy to plan attacks and avoid detection by providing the information necessary to do so. Consistency is key when making such a game that requires such precision, and whilst Klei’s latest stealth title, [i]Invisible, Inc.[/i], does a good job at making sure enemy and item interactions are the same every time, it does a poor job at explaining what they’re going to do in the first place.

A mission, for example, might require to hack into a specialised vault to acquire an expensive piece of technology. This makes sense, and you’ll scope out the level [i]X-COM: Enemy Unknown[/i] style, remaining undetected and feeling pretty good about the whole scenario until you peek through a door into the room with the vault. The game gives you a pop-up to let you know that you’ve found the target, and after hacking it using the method the game has instructed you to use in the tutorial, the item will disappear from your objectives list, indicating to any sensible human being that it has been completed. Still undetected, you’re feeling pretty great about this and you successfully get all of your agents to the designated level exit without them having been spotted. At this point, you’ll try to exit the level only for the game to advise you that you haven’t looted the vault correctly, and that whilst it has been opened, you haven’t actually taken anything from it.

What we have here is a failure to communicate. The first playthrough of this game will end disastrously through no fault of your own, but simply because the only real way to understand the mechanics is to try (and usually fail) to use them after the game’s shit-tier explanations fail to be of any help. It’s a shame, because hidden under all the frustrations is a genuinely good game. It has everything: a striking art style, fun cyberpunk setting, concise visual design. [i]Invisible, Inc.[/i]’s near-complete opacity and failure to tutorialise do little to usurp Klei as the pinnacle of indie game developers. Everything they make has such a unique and pointed vision about it, and good design permeates throughout all of the titles they put out. [i]Invisible, Inc.[/i] is no exception, it’s just not appropriate for casual players in ways that don’t seem entirely intentional.

An excellent blend of turn-based stealth and roguelike elements.

Invisible, Inc. is a game about a spy agency that gets raided by a mysterious corporate force - a small crew of just a handful of agents manage to escape; now you have to lead them on a quest to discover who tried to destroy the agency before their super-computer's back-up power runs out.
The general flow of the game is that you choose a mission based on probable rewards (ala XCOM 2), send in your agents to complete the mission, and then get them all to the extraction point before it gets bad. Although it's a turn-based, tactics-style game (again, think XCOM), the gameplay is basically all stealth-based, and it's done here extremely well. While you often have a few options for combat, it's usually best not to take them if you can help it - In the wrong circumstances, any enemy can be a threat. Being detected at all will always make the corporation more aware that you're there (which translates into more, tougher, and agressive enemies, so it's in your best interest to never be noticed at all.
The roguelike elements include permanent death for your team, randomized maps, and multiple agents to work with - each makes the game unique and interesting with each playthrough.

All in all, a very good stealth game with superb replayability.

41072275.review:
This is a game that sounds ludicrous to design on paper but somehow Klei aced it.  

It's a turn-based stealth game with no actions determined by RNG.  Yes, thats right, no missing a 95% shot at point blank in this game (no missing any shots period for that matter).  The game is balanced in somewhat 'board-game' fashion by an alarm tracker that advances every turn which introduces new obstacles the longer you take to accomplish your mission: dormant cameras activate, new guards spawn, eventually even your agent positions are broadcast if you don't accomplish your mission fast enough.  Every turn feels like there is pressure to accomplish something, yet you need to temper yourself with enough caution to not be seen.  To add to your decision anxiety, this is a game that saves every move.  Which means you really can loose and have to start all over because you misjudged that guard's sight radius during his patrol and aggro'd him and his friends.  Luckily the game blesses you with a set number of turn rewinds based on your difficulty...you will use them.  

Meanwhile the game tempts you to sack every level for cash which allows you to upgrade your agents.  Augments and items can greatly impact your individual agents playstyle so different playthroughs can feel fairly different based on the hand you're dealt in the early game.  There are also hacking abilities powered by a resource gained from the consoles scattered throughout the levels that allow you to do things like turn off cameras or take over robotic enemies.  All these gameplay variables make it feel like you're really having to grab what you can and adapt: like your agency which is on the run from corporations from the get-go.

This game delivered much more than I expected based on the premise of turn-based stealth.  It manages to present you with lots of decision points, there is hardly a moment in the whole game where you are not weighing semi-viable options against each other.  Highly recommended.

40436370.review:
Invisible, Inc. (formerly known as Incognitia) is a sci-fi turn based strategy with a short timeframe and generated levels. Set in a corporate espionage dominated dystopian future, players must take control of Invisible Inc., a fallen corp that must regroup and regain its power before its AI Incognitia's backup battery expires.

Invisible, Inc. feels like a child of XCOM: Enemy Unknown and Syndicate (the original Syndicate, not that new thing) with some roguelike aspects thrown in and a heavy emphasis on replayability. In-mission gameplay is focused on stealth gameplay, and the kind of patient, deliberate map control that XCOM: EU seems to encourage is eliminated by inherently weak player agents and a steadily ticking alarm counter. As the alarm counter climbs, additional hacking defences, cameras and security guards are brought into the level to keep players on their toes.

Alongside the turn based strategy gameplay, a hacking mechanic allows for doors, safes, cameras and so forth to be unlocked or disabled by Incognitia at the cost of power, which provides some light resource management gameplay as well.

Missions are focused on getting in and getting out as quickly and quietly as possible. Agent losses are massive blows, and with the game's short, 72 hour timeframe, the number of opportunities to gather more resources, equipment and agents always feels like it's barely enough, giving every successful run at a decent difficulty level a sense of being obtained by the skin of your teeth.

Invisible, Inc. manages to maintain a sense of risk and tension at all times, but still provides players with the tools to recover from poor decisions whilst simultaneously raising the stakes and challenging the player to make the best of the resulting situations.

The plot and pacing of Invisible, Inc. are both really well executed, and it's another great example of storytelling in a roguelike-ish game.

Invisible, Inc. has since had an expansion DLC released called Contingency Plan which extends the base campaign and adds in some more hacking abilities, equipment, agents and objectives.

A superb turn-based tactical roguelike game, Invisible Inc. hits the mark in every respect: 
- satisfying stealth - something rarely done well in games - 
- an excellent corperate dystopian aesthetic, with a developing story and characters, 
- team and gear upgrades that feel worth the effort 
- each playthrough gives a very different set of challenges, varying enemies and mission layouts or mission types that combined with a progressive campaign in which you have to work your socks off to progress each time 
- even if you find yourself re-running the same first few levels, the different characters, tools and upgrades you find will massively vary your play-through and playstyle to keep it fresh and rewarding
- the timer restriction for missions is subtle but devasting: as much as you want to hang about for ages getting all the credits and items you can, you absolutely [i]cannot[/i] afford to stay too long or the nice clear exit route will suddenly become a maze of security nightmares
- every tactical choice is important: limited use items are valuable, but run out of them and you're suddenly defenceless - but equally, you absolutely need them to survive - or, even more frequently - to ensure you make good time doing the mission and getting out. 
- even whether to explore with your whole group together or split them up becomes important - split them up and cover more ground, but also leave them much more vulnerable.
- finally, progression is perfect: it's damn hard, but you will find that as your methods and tactics evolve, so does your progress, and even when everything turns against you, you may discover a new item or implant that will have you redesign future plans in light of it
- an excellent soundtrack that absolutely captures the whole feel of the game

If you enjoy making detailed plans and changing them as the situation alters, this game is for you: each item, upgrade, implant or character you get will massively change your approach and increase your options for any given situation.

My only warning is this: never feel safe. There's always something worse awaiting you, and when you get cocky is when you get caught out by the relentless corperations - and losing a run can feel devasting when you had everything you should've needed.

The only downside to the game is that when your luck's seriously against you, you can lose a lot very quickly - for that reason, I do recommend playing with savegames available and a couple of time resets available per mission - at least to begin with: it can still feel very punishing even with them. 

Once you feel up for the challenge without either though, I offer you congratulations and good luck - you'll need it to beat the Corps!

Levels get very tense as you try to most optimally utilise your accumulated agents, augmentations, programs and items to counter increasingly difficult security. Sometimes you might lose an agent.. Is it worth trying to save them or cut your losses? The unique and clever abilities, augmentations and items, coupled with programs that have both their pros and drawbacks, makes for some incredible scenarios that seem straight out of a movie.
