39088350.review:
[h1]Rating[/h1]
[b]5/10[/b]

[h1]Worth it?[/h1]
In my opinion, no.

[h1]Playtime[/h1]
The main story is supposedly about 7-8 hours long.
I gave up after 5 hours.

[h1]Comparison[/h1]
It's a turn-based tactics game, with mechanics similar to the [b]XCOM[/b] series.

[h1]Plot[/h1]
The year is 2074 and mega-corporations rule the world.
You're a member of Invisible Inc., a private intelligence agency.
Your headquarters is compromised and only a handful of agents escape, along with a powerful AI system - Incognita.
Unfortunately, Incognita can't survive long on backup power. 
It becomes your mission to find a new power source for her and you have 72 hours to do that.

[h1]Look...[/h1]
All Klei Entertainment games have their distinctive styles and this is no exception.
The cyberpunk setting looks very well, with its corporate offices and sterile environments. It's very convincing and a pleasure to look at.

[h1]... and Feel[/h1]
The controls are simple enough. 
Unlike the new XCOM instalments, you don't deal with specific actions (move + attack), but good old Action Points. So you can perform multiple actions as long as remaining APs allow it.

[h1]Music[/h1]
When I was playing the game, I didn't really notice the background music.
But when I checked out the soundtrack separately, it's actually pretty good. 
It has this "corporate conspiracy" vibe to it, if that makes sense.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
At first you are presented with a world map and you have to pick your next mission. Each location requires time to get to, which subtracts from your 72 hours.
The game encourages multiple playthroughs, so the available missions on the map and the actual mission locations are procedurally generated.
Once a mission begins, your operatives are deployed to the selected location and you take control of them in a turn-based tactics game. 
You can switch between them freely, move them into strategic positions or perform various actions (open doors, peak around the corners, set up ambushes, operate equipment, etc.). In addition, you have Incognita, showing you the tactical view of the map and allowing you to hack different devices, disable cameras, traps or security robots. After you're done with your turn, the enemies make their moves, patrolling the area or investigating your activities.
Every five turns you take (or sometimes more often), the security level is increased, raising the guard's awareness, making machines harder to hack or even bringing reinforcements.
The game is all about stealth - trying to complete your goals and getting out, while avoiding cameras, traps and patrols. And since it gets more and more difficult over time, it's best to locate your objective and try to exfil as quickly as possible.
Here's the main problem I have with this game - using lethal force is discouraged. At the beginning it's not even available.
You can stun guards, which will take them out for 2 turns, while your stunning weapon is disabled for 3 turns. You have the option to upgrade your tools and buy new weapons, but money is also used to upgrade your agent's skills so you either do that or purchase new toys.
And that's another thing I didn't like - the shop outside of missions (Monst3r) rarely has anything useful for sale (seriously, by the time I completed three missions, he only had one item available). And shops in missions were randomly placed - when I had money, they had nothing interesting to offer, and the cool stuff was there only when I was broke. It's hard for me to believe that it was a design choice, seems more like bad luck on my part.
Without the option to get new equipment, this game seemed very limited in terms of gameplay variety. It was just: approach a room, stun the guard, run into the next room before the guard wakes up, repeat 3-4 times, get to the objective, rush to the exit, avoid all the guards that were previously stunned and are now back up and looking for you.

[h1]DLC[/h1]
The "Contingency Plan" DLC offers new agents, items, weapons, augments and programs for Incognita. The main campaign is also extended with some additional missions and challenges.
This was enabled during my playthroughs, so I can't really say which elements were from the main game and which from the DLC.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Maybe it was just me. Maybe the missions I've played during my 5 hours were generated in a way, that didn't allow me to experience the full potential of this game. I just don't feel like spending any more time to find out.
I'm an old [b]XCOM[/b] fan and I've also enjoyed previous Klei Entertainment's games (especially [b]Mark of the Ninja[/b]). With that said, I'm disappointed with Invisible Inc. and I can't recommend it.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
- cyberpunk setting
- graphics that match that setting very well
- good old Action Points

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- use of lethal force is discouraged
- shops rarely offer useful items
- wasted potential

The people at Klei have impressed me with their games since I first got my hands on a demo of Eets. Invisible Inc lives up to the already high standards I had for them. Once again they marry gameplay and style into a really fun package.

This is a stealth game at its heart, but throws in elements of hacker technology. While there isn't much story to be found each level is based around reconnaissance, meeting objectives, and then getting out. If you can grab some other resources along the way for future missions, all the better.

The game takes place in both the real world and in cyberspace. Agents can move around the level, trying to avoid being captured by guards, while the security gets tighter the longer they're inside. There are firewalls guarding anything worth accessing, but can be disarmed by programs, which take power to use. There are multiple ways to traverse levels, depending on the agents. You can collect credits to buy programs to infiltrate security, or you can spend credits on tools to do that for you. There's enough variety that you can try a few different play styles.

Replayability is very high. Levels are proceduraly generated, and you learn to apply different tactics through trial and error. Playing more means you unlock more agents and programs, giving you more tools to get past tighter security. If you're a fan of stealth and turn based tactics, this game is a must.

37838694.review:
Invisible, Inc. raises the bar for stealth games in a massive way. It is by far one of the best games I have played.

Without going into excessive detail, the biggest features that make it what it is:

- Depth: Many characters, game modes, user friendly settings for gameplay that  let you play what you want, how you want without punishing the player for doing so. You are free to approach the game with whatever strategy or "play style" you feel, and at no point does any tactic feel "not as intended" nor does the game too heavily favor or punish any of them. Any playstyle comes with stronger and weaker points for diffferent mission types or with different characters.

Unlike many titles with a variety of different characters to pick from, none of them are too similar, and none of them are too good, too bad, or not an asset to your team. One of the most fun things about the game, is figuring out how to use different characters together, to best make use of what they bring, and play to their individual strengths. The same (mostly) goes for the gear, upgrades, and other things you have in your arsenal as you play.

- Replayablity: So many "randomly generated procedural" games recently seem to be anything but. In efforts to make a game random, many end up being repetitive, bland, or (in the other direction) randomly punishing. Invisible, Inc. hits a very happy middle ground. Levels offer variety that is interesting without being unfairly random. 

Different game modes give you more to do once you've learned (or mastered) the game's mechanics. Especially endless, time attack, and harder modes. As you increase difficulty or add more challenge, the difficulty is not artificial - simply adding more hazards, or reducing resources. New, dangerous mechanics are actually introduced; guards will start patrolling through multiple rooms instead of remaining inside of one, sight lines can be hidden until you actually see an observer, for example.
There are so many possibly combinations both in what you start a campaign with, and what you can find (or the strategy you use to win) that there is always more to do.

- Respect for players' time: With the number of games being created these days, more and more players seem to be buying games based largely on the question of "will I get my money's worth?" or "will my time spent playing this be wasted?" Invisible, Inc. is neither a grind, nor boring. It has a bit of a steep learning curve, which can make it difficult to start with, but it never wastes the player's time. In this sense, it is somewhat like a rogue-like game, in that trial and failure are part of the game, and failing is practically always a product of the player's choices, not unfair, punishing, or random elements. It always gives you the opportunity to make the most informed choices (or not to) and the consequences of them are what make each turn exciting.

-Style: The setting, story, visuals, and music all come together to make a fantastic and unified game. Surprisingly immersive for an isometric turn-based strategy game, great realisation of the cyberpunk setting.

My only regret is that I've finished it and moved on to new(er) things!

Out of all the games I own, this is the one I come back to time and time again on a rather frequent basis. I would say I get the umption to play every two to three months. Play for a bit, take a break, then come back to it. Plus, there are a number of solid mods to add which extend the overall value tremendously from extra characters to AI behaviors and even tools which add more variety to the already fantastic procedurally generated tilesets.

The story isn't very deep, but it has great production value. I mean, there's not much you need from a Rogue-like. It provides just enough to give you an excuse to run around as a super-secret corporate spy.

The Contingency Plan DLC is worth the price. It brings greater challenge and depth and extends the overall experience--which in the Vanilla version feels a little too short. Not that it is short (maybe a hair) it's just that halfway through, you'll start to enjoy your team and the game so much, you'll just wish it would last longer.

The game is similar to X-Com but only in the fact that it's turn based. The objective is not to seek and destroy, but to hide and steal. There is no R&D sub-game to be found, however there is an economic system that can be quite challenging to maintain. This is a good thing and a bad thing. Obviously, an R&D system would be excellent, but I would not say you miss it in this game, since it is less the traditional Strategy Campaign and more the Rogue-like. The game is meant to be quick, fast-paced, and challenging.

The game is literally dripping with style. All of the agents are cool, even the Community-built Mod agents. You'll have your favorites, for sure, but they all provide an interesting playstyle.

The only major flaw in the game that I can see is that throughout my playtime, I've noticed I end up using the same Augments and Gear and Programs from one playthrough to the other. There is definitely a hierarchy where this is concerned, and I think it's the weakest aspect to the game. It doesn't take away from the challenge or the enjoyment, but I wish there had been more attention paid to the balance in these aspects. In other words, some Gear is just clearly better than other Gear. Not in the capacity that it's simply better, but in the capacity that the lesser gear simply isn't that useful. Same with Augments and Programs.

One area of Critique that is not necessarily a flaw, but definitely one can see its missed opportunity is the World Map. Most folks who would play this are expecting an XCom experience, and I wouldn't blame them for it. As such, the World Map simply begs for some kind of base-management system. I agree and disagree with this, though I can see that it is a missed opportunity for some depth. Basically, I do not agree that this game needs a Base-Building mechanic. Once you play the game and understand the nature of the story and how the count-down system works, you'll understand, but something like a Base-Building mechanic simply wouldn't make sense in context to the game or the story. However, there could have been opportunity for something like we find in the game Evil Genius where you manage assets and henchment on the World Map. At any rate, the game doesn't feature anything like this, and it is definitely the one thing that I constantly think about which might have made the difference.

Overall, this game is great at full price, and it's a steal on discount. If you like Turn-based Strategy with a lite element of Rogue-like--this is the game for you. You will not be disappointed--I guarantee it.

Invisible, Inc is a hybrid of XCOM ( the grid based map and covers ), FTL (using money to upgrade your ship or buy weapons, and allowing you to choose your path between points until you reach your destination), and stealth games. It is an interesting game, but there are some places that can be improved.

In FTL, you have some stuff to do at the beginning: while you try to go through as many points as possible, use the money you've earned to prioritize the shield, and the game ensures you to have enouth battles to get the money. Only after that can you start to enjoy the randomness of the game, then you can apply different strategies based on what kind of ship you've chose and what weapons or systems you have. While the way the missions are arranged in Invisible, Inc are similar to FTL, they have something that makes a lot of difference: freedom. 

You would find out that if you don't have a rescue agent mission in the first day, it really increases the difficulty so much that you might just want to restart your run. Also, if you happen to go to points that are close to each other, in the second day the points would be super far from you to compensate that, as if the game designer wants the player to only go through 7 or 8 points before 72 hours. In FTL, you feel smart when you find out a path that maximizes the points you traveled and escaped to the next sector just before the rebels caught you. But in Invisible, Inc, you don't have as much strategy involved, the advantage you've got today, you'll loose it tomorrow. And while we know we want to go to get the password first, then go to labs or vaults to maximize the profit, we may not see the password mission while we have a lot of vault, lab missions, or vice versa based on randomness.

The randomness takes too much portion of the entire game, and hurts the strategy part of it. Different from The Binding of Isaac, where the random items are the whole point of the game, Invisible, Inc is a strategy game which should have more in players control. If you die in The Binding of Isaac, you only loose 10~20 min progress, but if you die in day 2 or day 3 in Invisible, Inc, you are loosing 2~3 hours of progress, which harms the passion for me on keep trying to beat the game in expert difficulty. Not getting good missions is not the only random part that hurts Invisible, Inc, but also the map and the virus in every mission. It might be until alarm level 4 when you  find where your objective is, and that might be in the opposite position on the map where the exit is. Also, it is very common that once a guard comes in, the chain effect starts and you not only have additional 1.5 more alarm levels in just 1 turn, but also the unknown virus might just bring you huge trouble while it's on a vital device that you have to hack. If these bad conditions happen in the late game, you most likely would loose your entire squad and would have to restart your run for better luck. After loosing multiple 2~3 hours progress, I've gave up on this game. It's just depressing hearing the old lady shouts "Stop playing on people's lifes!" and blames you on that while you've tried your best but couldn't stop the guards shooting your agents.


You might say that you can abandon the mission if you feel it is too hard for you and you should not try to accomplish every mission, but the fact is, that means you've wasted 9~12 hours in game and just got 400 dollors or so. When this piles up you would definetly fail the final mission, or the middle mission that is after 72 hours, the guards would be stronger nomatter whether you've abbandomed the mission or not, so you kind of have to complete every mission to get the cash to buy the upgrades or weapons.

I don't like the policy of the DLC too. Although I bought it with the DLC, I think this game would be very awkward without it. Imagine The Binding of Isaac with 4 floors in total, FTL with 3 sectors then you fight the flag ship, or Spelunky with only 8 levels. It would give people a feeling that "This is a good concept, but feels wrong somewhere, and needs to be polished". I think the game should include the DLC and raise the price to avoid people that only bought the vanilla game feel bad about it.

To summarize, Invisible, Inc has good ideas but needs to be polished. You may not feel this in easier difficulty, but when you start the expert difficulty, which the game says "this is the difficulty that is meant to be played", you would start to see the flaws of the design. I like Invisible, Inc that it tried to combine various ideas together to make a new game, and appreciate it made most of the missions exciting (the rest are "Ah, there's nothing we can do, lets give up and start a new run  _(:з」∠)_  "), but still can't recommand it to others since I've played better rougelikes.

In no other game have I found myself teetering on the brink of failure, toeing the line of how far I can go while still successfully completing the mission, and balancing greed versus risk while still remaining entirely in control.

Every infiltration starts off slow, exploring the area and learning guard patrol paths.  The threat level gradually amps up, and by the time you've reached the main objective it's turned into a full-on sprint for the exit.

The variety of items present leaves you with plenty of options when in a sticky situation, and the subtle but still notable differences between agents makes each playthrough unique.  Indeed, the game is designed to be played through multiple times, with new agents and programs unlocked after every successful or failed campaign.  Such replay value, with randomly generated levels and a range of difficulty levels (that actually change gameplay, rather than being the usual health/damage increase most games profess), is a large part of my recommendation.

Oh, and the music is awesome.  It gets more intense depending on what has happened; by the time your agents have entered combat and made their way to the exit, the calm ambiance has become fast-paced and beat-driven.

I bought it on sale but can say that it's certainly worth full price.

36472748.review:
Inivisible Inc is a stealth game where you play as agents trying to navigate the different difficulties of a single level map. 

Gameplay-wise, it's a top down view where you control your agents and activate them based on an Action Point system. You will see similarities from other classic stealth games like Commando, like being able to read the enemy's viewcone. For Invisible Inc, you can have up to a maximum of 4 agents for each mission. Each agent has similar stats that can be upgraded. However, each agent will have a special augment that differentiates them. Every map is procedurally generated based on difficulty level and objective. The missions come in hostage rescue, CEO vault access card, vault access, Nanofabricator, sitelist and augment missions. The general formula is go to some place, access something, escape. Rinse and repeat.

The most common thing that you will be using is the super AI called Incognita and her Mainframe system. This is where you will see similarities to Transistor. In the Mainframe mode, you will hack the different features in the game. Normally, you will convert power to reducing the security level to 0. Once the feature hits 0, it will be hacked and you will gain access to its ability. E.g. Hacking a camera will give you vision of said camera. To get more power, you have to hack consoles which doesn't make much sense.

Conclusion, Invisible Inc is an interesting game but it's definitely not a top-tier stealth game. The graphics kind of reminds me of Transistor but with less fancy effects. The gameplay is a mix of XCOM and Commando. Story is faily simple but at least there is a continuation.

[h1][b]PROS[/b][/h1]
1. Continuation of Story
I think the ending with the DLC points to more expansions of the series and hopefully more interesting versions of Invisible Inc. [spoiler]Incognita becomes the main villain at the end[/spoiler]

2. Stealth 
I love stealth games. Even though there are certain lame ideas that are repeated like duck-walking, vents and crouching.

[h1][b]CONS[/b][/h1]
1. Stupid AI Scenarios
You can stand next to the guard.

2. Game Time is Too Short
Like really short. The beginner campaign with DLC is over in 9 hours. Considering that Klei utilizes procedurally generated maps, it's strange that it's so short. There is an Endless mode so there is proof that map generation is simple to do.

3. DLC doesn't add Much Content
According to the description, without the DLC, the game is just a demo. There's 4 more heroes, more abilities, more types of enemies and an additional stage on Day 4.  However, when you play it, it's like a normal game.

4. Crouching, crouching, crouching
There's so much crouching in a high tech environment. I'm expecting more invisible cloaks, disguises, hacking of guard communications and overriding security controls.

5. Teleporters Every Stage
Wow. Every single Secnet building has a teleporter to escape with. How convenient. The escape route just being there every level is odd. Surely, there could be something cooler? E.g. Masquerading as a guard and escaping. 

6. Same Agents
Theoretically, all agents are the same. They have the same stats that can be bought. There should be more differentiation with the augments and less with the stats.

[h1][b]SUGGESTIONS[/b][/h1]
1. Locking Doors with Incognita
I want to try a scenario where you lock the enemy out by hacking a door.

2. Multi-levels
Everything is on just 1 level. It's like the architect decided to work on one floor only. How about making multiple floors? Like level 1, 2 and 3. That way agents can be spread over different levels. E.g. Turning off the power generator in the basement to turn off the lights.

3. Multi-levels : Elevators and Stairs
So much cooler to ride the elevator or sneak up the stairs. Just use mouse wheel to change the view between the floors. Alternatively, F1 for floor 1, F2 for floor 2 and F3 for floor 3.

4. Light and Darkness
Everything is lighted. Where's the darkness in a stealth game? How about being able to turn off the lights? Guards can't see that well in the dark and you can sneak past them. This also leads to better equipment like night vision goggles.

36075154.review:
It's one of the best games I have ever played. It beautifully merges the mechanics of a turn-based strategy title like XCOM or Jagged Alliance with something like Metal Gear Solid or Splinter Cell. Turn based stealth may seem to be a weird concept in theory, but it is executed wonderfully here.

One playthrough of the campaign will probably take you only a couple of hours, but here's the deal; every playthrough allows you to unlock new means (agents and programs) to tackle the increasingly difficult obstacles you are faced with.
Maps are randomly generated, so the game offers nigh-endless replayabilty and you are constantly left wanting for more (which is evidenced by the time I've spend playing this title). 
What is more, different combinations of agents and programs you start with, force you to alter your strategy (i. e. while it is usually wiser to knock people out, some characters like Draco from the DLC might actually gain benefits if you rack up a lot of kills early on) so you can experiment with different playstyles as well.

The aesthetics of the game are gorgeous; the graphics and artsyle give a wonderful vibe, the music perfectly sets up the mood of the game (it starts slow, but gradually becomes more frantic as the situation grows more dire) and the voice acting is really good (although it is used rather sparingly).

I enjoy a challenge in games like this and I am happy to say I find the difficulty of the game to be great as well. You can choose from many difficulty levels, and it seems it is best to play through them all in order to get acquianted with all the mechanics of the game. You genuinely have to get better at the game to tackle the harder settings.
If at any point you'll find a single element of the gameplay is not to your liking, you can choose the 'custom' difficulty which gives you a lot of reedom to tweak the gameplay exactly as you want it (to make the game easier/harder as you see fit).

As a fan of both the new XCOM titles and stealth games I can confidently say this is the game I've always been waiting for and I can wholeheartedly recommend it. 

Still, I understand this is not a title for everyone. Turn based stealth is a rather novel concept and it may not be to everyone's liking. However, If you found anything I wrote here even remotely appealing, you would be doing yourself a great disservice by not trying this game out.

[h1]----- SUMMARY -----[/h1]

Grade : F D C B A [b]<< S >>[/b]
Main Pro: Rich variety of deliberate, to-the-point tactics
Main Con: Unrealized plot potential

[h1]----- FULL REVIEW -----[/h1]

Invisible Inc. is easily the best [strike]door-opening simulator[/strike] turn-based strategy game I've ever played. Why, you ask? Let's get right to it: Invisible Inc. doesn't mess around much with fluff and neither will I!

Perhaps one of the most defining characteristics of this game is that it employs the use of heroes (aka agents) without using traditional RPG leveling. Instead, nearly everything (stat upgrades, skills, items) is purchased with money, and you can divy it up as you so choose. Efficiency and progression, then, is often defined by how well you complete a mission, not how much you utilized a particular hero.

Why am I bringing this up? By removing the need for confrontation--and by extension the experience it normally brings,--the depth of tactics you can effectively employ becomes massive. Want to be dodgy by using cloaks and hologram projectors? Do that. Want to run a power-hungry setup so you can hack all the computers and drones? Sure. Or maybe you really do want to punch every security guard you find square in the face? Absolutely! Invisible Inc. can be such a surprise at times, as I constantly discover new nuances and ways to navigate my way through sticky situations.

And believe me, things can get very sticky. Make no mistake: Invisible Inc. can get bonkers tough. Foes are predictable but lethal. An alarm tracker increases with each passing turn, periodically dropping new countermeasures on your squad. The procedural generation aspect of the game means you'll stay guessing... but that's actually another remarkable aspect of this game. As stealth can have an "information warfare" dimension to it, Invisible turns what can be a weakness of procedural generation into one of its greatest strengths. Suspense can run high, but threading the needle on a harrowing infiltration has almost no equal for me in the strategy genre. Watching a strategy you personally concocted "beat the odds" can make for some incredible moments.

If I had one major complaint to throw out there, its the story. Look, story isn't a focus of this game, and you should know that going in. Despite that, I was severely disappointed in how the game ended. The basic narrative that's set up is fairly compelling but the game is content to use a very cliche, punch-in-the-face kind of ending that comes out of nowhere (although the DLC story expansion does a better job of setting things up.) I despised it so much, I felt as if I would have rather not had an ending!

There are a couple of other thorns that could bother some people more than others. One of the few places the game does use RPG leveling is with starting loadout unlocks; this isn't a huge problem as you really should get one solid playthrough under your belt before you start havey-duty scheming, but I imagine some might find it frustrating. The story's endgame missions can have a sometimes startling difficulty spike, although some actually find that endearing.

Either way, these low points are more like speed bumps than walls. These things are a lot easier to forget when the core gameplay loop is so stupid fantastic. I wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of turn-based strategy games. And... yeah. Its amazing. That's pretty much it. Buy it and join the face-kicking... though I don't make any guarantees over which side will be doing the face-kicking initially. ;)

Possibly the best stealth game ever, beating out Thief and Klei's own Mark of the Ninja. This is turn-based gameplay distilled to perfection. Unlike X-Com, you won't feel OP at any point, and every action counts.

One of the weaker points is the meta-campaign. More narrative would have helped, as would have more mission variety. In fact, a little bit more strategy between missions would really have broken up the tension and given the player time to recover. On the other hand, it's really hard to do a meta-campaign that works well and doesn't detract from a tactical game. X-Com did it once (and even that is debatable), and everyone since has been trying to copy the formula. Also, the ending is a problem. From a narrative perspective, it's really good narratively, but it won't inspire you to try the game again at a higher difficulty, which is what the game expects you to do.

In addition, there's a ton of knobs to mess with to make the game harder as you learn the systems better, and the community has made mods to take the difficulty to the next level. There's one item that seems a little broken to me, in that it makes parts of the game too easy, but I can easily remedy that with mods.

All in all, this game is superb and highly recommended. As I said above, it's the best stealth game ever made, and it may also be the best tactics game ever made.

XCOM, but without the randomness.

Like XCOM, you play a series of turn based tactical missions on randomised maps, with a world map and team progression that ties them together.  Missions take 1-2 hour, maps are procedurally generated, there's one main objective that gives you something useful (a super loot container, a super shop terminal, an agent to rescue, etc.), loads of other things to loot on the way, threats to avoid, and one teleporter you escape through.  There's a lot of variety to keep each mission interesting.

Big difference 1)  Once you're in a mission there's no randomness. Guards follow fixed patterns; they don't teleport around until you spot them; your shots never miss (neither do theirs...), you can normally spot every surprise before it happens (peeking through doors and around corners, peeking at guard to see where they move next).  It can be challenging but it's always fair and it feels like every mission is doable if you play it right and you don't get greedy (which is really impressive given that it's procedurally generated).

Big Difference 2)  Semi-ironman with the Rewind mechanic.  If you make a mistake (or just missclick, I did that a lot), you can rewind back to the start of your previous turn.  You only have limited uses per mission (3 on normal, 1 on hard, you can set it to 0), so it's not a free ticket (it's a very expensive ticket) and you can't use it to cheat RNG because there is no RNG.  I think it's a great for people like me without the time or patience for real ironman modes but do like have decisions matter.

Oh, and the 2D art and animation looks beautiful.

Edit: I recommend the UI Tweaks mod (http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=581951281), doesn't break achievements but does fix a few things.

32370549.review:
"Invisible, Inc." is a one-of-a-kind and an instant classic. As a turn-based strategy game, it requires a high level of planning and strategy to succeed. This is compounded by the "rouguelike" aspect of the game, meaning that you are not allowed to reload a previous save if you screw up. Depending on the difficulty level you choose, you may either have the ability to retry the level, use a limited number of "rewinds" which bring you back to the beginning of the previous turn, or, on "ironman mode," have no safety net at all, meaning if you lose your team it is time to start a new game.

This unforgiving style is compounded by the seemingly unfairness of the fight. You are outnumbered and outgunned, infiltrating unknown enemy territory (levels are randomly generated), and you must rely on your stealth and cunning to make it through. Still, there are a number of tools at your disposal: distraction techniques, lethal and non-lethal attacks, a wide variety of powers and gadgets that range from traps to cloaking devices, and a hacking system that targets the various devices found in the level allowing you to access, disable, or remotely command them.

While there are some random elements to the game that vary the way each run plays out (such as which types of missions are available, the layouts of each level, and items/powers you find on the way), the rest of the game is very deterministic. If you are very careful and diligent, you can play the enemy like a fiddle, pulling them this way and that so that your other agents can reach the mission objective (and/or rob the corporations blind). However, screw-ups do happen, and when they do, the situation can plunge from "astounding success" to "catastrophic failure" very quickly. There is no HP meter for your agents. If they are shot, they are permanently downed until another agent either drags them to the exit (leaving them vulnerable in the process) or revives them with Med Gel (which you may have inconveintly left behind to make room for that fantastic new gadget). It is possible to go on without them, but later missions are only going to be harder and it may be next-to-impossible to succeed with an under-manned team.

Hacking is a vital part of the game in order to get past cameras and drones - and to access the various "shops" that come in the form of firewalled terminals found inside the levels. The hacking system is, in some ways, a game within a game. You can switch between the "real world" and the "virtual world" of your A.I., Incognita. Everything she does requires power. Power can be generated by programs within Incognita, or through the actions of your agents (such as using their cybernetic augments or ordering them to hack consoles). This adds yet another layer of complexity to the game. If you are being hunted by guards and barely staying afloat, the last thing you want is to run out of power and get spotted on camera because you couldn't hack it. It leads to situations where you are running risky maneuvers in order to get to consoles, just so you can proceed unhindered through the rest of the level. The number of hazards, and their respective firewall levels, is increased each turn, so careful planning and efficient power usage is essential.

In the end, the beauty of "Invisible, Inc." is its balance and the choices it forces you to make. It is both ruthlessly hard and extremely satisfying when you make it through a level without a hitch. You must choose between dodging past enemies, knocking them out for a couple turns, or killing them, each of which has its own concequences. You have to choose between that awesome gadget or a new hacking program that will help you with the increasingly difficult firewalls. You may have to choose to end your campaign or limp along with an under-manned team because your agent was seperated from the rest of the team and shot. This, and the huge variety of strategies available, make it a wildly satisifying experience. I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys strategy games.

Invisible, Inc. takes the old school hi-tech international super spy routine that Archer loves to parody and turns it into a riveting and deep turn-based strategy game.

What to expect:
-A world map with a selection of missions that must all be completed within seventy-two hours of in-game time.
-Mission goals can involve securing loads of money, weapons, system upgrades or new party members
-Mission maps are facility interiors divided into Fire Emblem-style squares. Your units (minimum of two and maximum of four) have a set number of actions in one turn, consumed by moving, peeking around corners, attacking enemies and more.
-A cast of super spies with unique abilities and stats. As you progress, money that you steal can be used to upgrade them, buy them weapons, install augmentations into them or buy them tools.
-Also under your control is a computer system called Incognita. This system can hack into the various consoles during missions to unlock money, weapons, upgrades, as well as disable security cameras, robots and more. Resources for Incognita hacking are limited, so be careful with your points.
-Several difficulty levels and many options to customize a campaign. One campaign may involve six or seven missions before the finale.
-Plot and story and characters are paper-thin. Honestly, that's just the window-dressing. Just focus on the really, in-depth strategy elements, alright?
-Music consists of moody, dark spy themes that blend in with the technology and hacking theme of the game.
-Art style depicts our characters and world in jagged, pointed shapes illuminated by bright colors just like computer monitors. I don't think anyone smiles once during this game. While the tone isn't unicorns-and-rainbows, it really isn't miserable and drained of life like a Zack Snyder film.

In conclusion, Invisible, Inc. is a solid purchase for any strategy fan. There's a lot of depth and complexity, which is how I like my games. Prepare to spend a lot of mental energy into grasping and utilizing these mechanics to your advantage. I recommend trying out a few campaigns in the Easy mode first.

31496964.review:
I rarely write reviews on Steam, and I really wanted to leave a good one for this game.

Unfortunately, I can't bring myself to recommend it, after playing it for over 30 hours and beating it a few times. It's a game that is so close to being excellent, but falls just short, making it all the more disappointing.

One of the key issues is that all upgrades throughout your run rely on the same currency. Credits are what you spend on items, upgrades to your hacking system, weapons, and character stats. For this reason, a typical playthrough will leave you short-changed in one area or more, even if you loot every safe in the level. For example: even if you net yourself 1500 credits (which is definitely well above average), that will maybe buy you an extra weapon, OR a hacking ability, OR a character implant, OR 1-2 stat upgrades. And remember, all characters have 4 stat categories to choose from, making it feel like you spent all that time and risked your life for very little. The game has a nasty habit overall of feeling stressful and unrewarding. You're very lucky to scrape by with your characters' lives when you clear an entire area, and you're not rewarded proportionally. There is no such thing as an overpowered run, which you might expect every few runs in a normal procedurally generated game. 

The second biggest issue for me are guard behavior and patrols. You'll learn quickly that the best way to succeed in Invisible Inc. is to not KO every guard you pass, even if its stealthily--rather you're better off circumventing them completely, as that is the only way to keep them in predictable patterns. This is much easier said than done however, as many generated levels will have a single long hallway, 3 tiles wide, as the only way to proceed to the goal or exit. These areas are nearly imposible to sneak through, especially with a squad of 3-5 characters. Even when guards are in their predictable patterns, they can still easily walk right into your characters before you even knew they existed on the level. It is not uncommon for a guard to walk right into your characters' starting room the second you end your first turn, putting you in a tight or even inescapable spot immediately. "Playing it safe" doesn't help in this sense; even if you stack up every door and peek it, a guard has enough AP to come from 2 rooms over straight into your room before you knew they were there. 

Where it gets unmanagable is when you alert guard(s) to your presence. If you are spotted (and there are many ways for your enemy to do so), you are put into overwatch where your character can move one tile into safety in order to survive. it's a crapshoot if you're in a position to escape these confrontations; many times all 8 possible tiles are watched by the enemy and will result in your death. Escaping these situations can be thrilling, but the fact is that the guard(s) that spotted you will be searching the map for the rest of the level. They will never go back to patrols. There is no way to predict where they will search next; as usual you cand spend an action point to observe their movement on the next turn but the place that they choose after finishing a search is entirely random and more often than not results in another character getting found or stuck in a corner. Later levels have guards that throw search grenades instead of walking directly to the area of interest, frequently putting a character into a neverending game of cat and mouse as your character can't get far enough away each turn to prevent their location being discovered.

All of this would be fine if you could spend the time learning the game's mechanics, mastering them, and getting good at the game. This is true only to the slightest extent: you can learn how to play, how to hide, how to avoid confrontation and what skills, characters, and items are useful. But after mastering the game's mechanics, You'll learn that there is no way to master the RNG related to guard behavior and level generation. These problems are only exacerbated by your complete lack of items and currency to buy the things you need to succeed. You will never have enough items, weapons, or skills in a given playthrough. And this isn't a case of "thinking carefully where you want to spend your credits", as there are many builds that are completely unviable and many failed runs where you looted every source of credits imaginable. 

Overall this lead me to constant frustration with a game that is so nearly great. It has an excellent framework and excellent mechanics that are fun to learn and thrilling when they rarely come together in a sucessful run. Unfortunately it is too rare to rely on as a fun, rewarding, and replayable rogue-like. I could recommend this game only to people as a sort of extremely difficult game to beat once, like those tough as nails platformers or something similar. But if you're expecting a rogue-like that you can replay endlessly, you'll have to look elsewhere, as this game will only leave you frustrated, exhausted, and stressed--even when you win.

Hope this helps you make a decision!

Invisible, Inc. is one of the best tactics games ever devised -- certainly the best I have ever played. This is why:

Turn-based stealth that actually works, with a number of interesting twists (hacking, character progression, a very interesting item system where each item has a tactical niche and an array of enemies, all of which have their own tactical niche as well). It's apparently very modular in how it's coded, too, meaning easy moddability, and even though there aren't an enormous number of mods (this game does have a fairly small audience compared to other Klei games) the mods that do exist are quite high-qualify, serving to enhance an already-fantastic game rather than being necessary to make the game enjoyable as can sometimes happen with games built around moddability.

In addition to the impressive campaign, which has you doing missions within a limited timeframe (which you can set in campaign generation, by the way, for a longer or shorter campaign) before a final confrontation, there is an Endless mode where difficulty will ramp up over the days just as in the campaign, except that the difficulty limit is much higher because, well, it's endless.

I also love the way in which randomness is used here. Levels are procedurally generated -- which, by extension, means that guard placements and loot are also procedurally generated. But that's about it. This game is often compared to X-COM, and there are some similarities, but the fact that there is no "chance-to-hit" is an extremely important difference. If your agent has been spotted by a guard, you need to either break line of sight (without moving the spotted agent more than 1 tile; if they move from a watched tile to another watched tile they will be shot instantly) or neutralize (stun or kill) the alerted guard. All of this is governed by tightly designed rules, rather than the dice.

Also, you can customize the difficulty settings.

This is a very big deal. All of the factors that go into determining how hard the game is, you can change them individually instead of being frustrated that "Experienced is too easy but Expert is too hard" or something. Seriously, this is a fantastic way to approach difficulty scaling and more games need to implement it.

If you like turn-based games, or stealth games, or both, give this one a try. It's an amalgam of game concepts which seems like it shouldn't work, but in fact does so beautifully. In my opinion this is the most well-designed tactics computer game ever -- it creates uncertainty through random level generation, but without the game's mechanics being subject to randomness as is the case with too many other tactics games.

Invisible, Inc. is a game developed and published by Klei Entertainment, the same people behind Mark of the Ninja. Invisible, Inc. is simply one of the best single-player games I've ever played

Absolutely incredible game with great replay value. To illustrate, here are some highlights from my playthrough history (I wrote them all down because I was so excited to try new combinations of agents and programs after my first few runs) (warning: SPOILERS for unlockable agents and programs):

1. Beginner, Decker + Internationale, Power Drip + Lockpick 1.0: Victory!
2. Experienced, Shalem 11 + Banks, Fusion + Parasite: Defeat!
4. Experienced, Internationale + Central, Faust + Brimstone: Victory!
6. Expert, Archive Dr. Xu + Prism, Dynamo + Rapier: Victory!
11. Expert Ironman, Decker + Archive Shalem 11, Fusion + Lockpick 1.0: Victory!
12: Expert Plus with DLC, Archive Decker + Draco, Seed + Golem: Victory!
13. Time Attack, Archive Banks + Dr. Xu, Power Drip + Parasite: Victory!
15. Endless Plus with DLC, Archive Prism + Derek, Fusion + Parasite: survived over 20 days

The main reason I could play the game so many times is that the main campaign is relatively short (maybe 6-8 hours? x1.5 with the DLC enabled). This to me was actually part of the game's charm: because there are many ways your playthrough can go (which missions are offered, which agents you can rescue, which items you can buy; all of which are limited in a single playthrough), each playthrough really feels like you are making the most of what's presented to you to build up your team. And it is NOT the case that you will reach a point where you are definitively "ready for the final mission." The final mission will happen when it happens, and sometimes you will go into thinking you're not prepared because you botched a couple earlier missions, but you will actually manage to succeed. This happened to me more than once, and along with other aspects of the game leads me to believe the game is very well balanced. I like as a design choice that you can mess up along the way but still recover.

Not to mention the mods that the community has created. I just finished my 16th playthrough overall, but the first with a mod enabled (Shogal's Rescuable Archive Agents mod), and about to start my 17th, ready now to enable several mods at once, allowing for new agents, programs, items and enemies. The game's mechanics are easy to understand but hard to master. I'm excited to take what I've learned and apply them to a new challenge.

TL;DR: One of my all-time favourite (turn-based strategy/tactics) games; think XCOM: Enemy Unknown but shorter/with a greater focus on replayability, and less RNG/more procedurally-generated challenges. No manual saving allowed, but 1-5 "undos" per mission depending on difficulty keeps tension high without being overly punishing. DLC adds flavour but the base game is definitely already complete without it.

This game has given me more than 80 hours of joy (with many more to come), and it's time for me to give back.

I would like to preface by saying I got this game on sale during the last Winter sale. Was it worth $7 including DLC? Absolutely. Is it worth $24 with said DLC? Debateable, depending on how much you're sold on this game before buyinig it. Invisible Inc. is an amalgamation of many different things that I love in video games. It's a procedurally-generated, turn-based stealth game with a cyberpunk aesthetic. 

You start each campaign with two agents, and it's up to you to direct them through the sprawling, massive levels to accomplish the objectives, whatever they may be. There are four different corporations for you to infiltrate, with locations all around the world. They each have their own strengths and unique units to make life harder for your agents. But the agents are unique too. While you initially only start out being able to choose 2 at the beginning of the  campaign, you unlock many more by gaining XP at the end of each playthrough, whether you succeed or not. Each agent has unique starting skills and abilities, but you can re-spec them throughout a campaign to suit your own, unique playstle. You also gradually unlock new starting programs, which are used for the hacking mechanic. All of Invisible Inc's missions contain hackable items. You can hack a camera and make their eyes into your own, or you can hack into a safe and uncover credits or items. Hacking costs PWR, which is very limited, so it isn't the solution to everything.

Concerning the campaigns, every playthrough is unique. While they begin and end with the same mission types, the level layout and location are always different. Now, the campaign itself is quite short, taking place over the course of just 72 hours, or 120 if you get the DLC. This can be a problem for some people, as you may simply not get the right missions in order to be prepared for the brutal final assault at the end. I personally, don't get mad when I have to start over, because it just means I get to play more Invisible Inc.

The missions (you'll have time for about 5-7 of them in a 72 hour campaign), are thrilling high-risk, high-reward endeavors that provide a lot of memorable moments. There are many different mission types, such as robbing corporate vaults or accessing a server farm. They each present their own unique challenges; crack that vault open, and enforcer units will arrive to investigate the location. Universally, though, all missions have a turn limit of sorts. Even if your agents remain completely undetected, without disturbing any sentries, the alarm level gradually ramps up each turn. When the alarm stage increases, the mission becomes more difficult. Additional cameras activate, more guards arrive, and they eventually pinpoint your location. You spend the entire time stalked by this turn counter, so every move counts. In addition to main objectives, you may stumble across a side-mission that unlocks additional awards if completed. They're rather limited in the base game, but the DLC adds many more.

The story is rather minimal, which I found disappointing just because of the interesting universe that is implied by the parts we do see. The dev team was pretty small, and only three characters receive voice acting. For a team this small, I'm glad they focused on the gameplay, but your mileage may vary.

Overall, Invisible Inc is an absolutely thrilling experience that I recommend to anyone who enjoys turn-based tactics, stealth, or just cyberpunk in general. If you're interested but not fully convinced, then just wait for it to go on sale. I, for one, am happy to give Klei my money so they can hopefully make games like this, and perhaps, one day, a sequel.

Simply one of the best single-player games I've ever played.

The theme is evoked well and the mechanisms of play are finely tuned. The real genius though, lies in how the game handles mistakes. In many games failure just costs time, or you are forced to reload whenever you make a mistake. Invisibles Inc. also allows this, but it really shines when you set up a game without rewinds or reloads. Then you get to experience how good a game can really be. The perfectly executed stealthy infiltration can quickly become a deadly game of cat and mouse, and successfully pulling unconscious agents out of a botched operation is way more satisfying than a reload could ever be.

Points of reference could be XCOM or the best roguelikes, like Brogue, but I think Invisibles Inc. outclasses them all.

You are a team of half-machine secret agent ninjas teleporting into buildings and stealing everyone's stuff without being seen. This is what all stealth games should be.

A bold move by Klei, the king of bold moves in videogames, this is an isometric turn-based PvE cyberspy simulator, and it goes much better than you'd think. It's 2074 and government has been replaced by evil supercorporations, so your targets are one of four of them who own all the credits and shiny plasma guns. 

Gameplay consists of ninja-ing around buildings, predicting guard patrols, stealing items, hacking mainframe devices to use to your advantage, and trying not to get annihilated by the constant barrage of unforseen threats. A lot of this game's fun lies in getting fucked over halfway through a mission and having to dig yourself out, i.e., getting spotted by an unnoticed guard and alerting the whole building, security daemons that give you negative status effects, or just being an idiot and having no way to undo your mistake (You get 1-5 rewinds depending on difficulty). Invisible Inc. does not forgive, and I'm glad it doesn't, because then the missions wouldn't be mind-shatteringly tense to play, and incredibly rewarding to beat.

As per Klei, the art direction is beautiful. The bloom from glowing hallways, the stylised futuristic theme, and the subtle screen effects, like distortion when activating Incognita (Hacker mode) make for an incredibly nice game to look at, admire, admire too hard, die, and admire the game over screen. The game over screen is also beautiful, because it along with the mission report gives you a plethora of information on how you were the most unprofessional spy agency on the planet. Another lovely thing about the levels is the tantalising prospect of the perfect run: nobody sees you, you loot every safe, hack every camera, complete the objective, and leave before anyone even realises you were there. This is a rare occurrence, but when it happens, it's like thunderous applause from every human being on Earth.

The soundtrack... the soundtrack. It's exquisite. It's everything I could've ever asked for from this theme. The music ramps up gradually as security tightens, going from foreboding background strings to "Everything is insanity and red flashing alarms and on fire". It adds SO much to the game. Just - just listen to it. Go and look it up. It's masterful.


£15 to be a cyberninja. Yes, Klei, that will do.

Invisible, Inc. es un juego del género ci-fi noir (también conocido como "tech noir"), un híbrido de mis dos géneros favoritos: el género negro y el de ciencia ficción, así que, naturalmente, tenía que jugarlo. El videojuego te pone en el pellejo de un operador-estratega que dirije a los agentes de una corporación de espionaje en misiones alrededor del globo con distintos objetivos, ya sea robar fondos para subvencionar nuevas tecnologías (microchips, nano-circuitos cibernéticos, implantes sintéticos y toda la pesca en plan Ghost in the Shell) con las que convertir a nuestros espías en verdaderos Inspectores Gadget o Terminators, robar esta tecnología directamente de las bases del enemigo o conseguir información valiosa para desbloquear nuevos objetivos que poder "saquear". Cada partida empieza eligiendo a dos agentes determinados (hay dos para elegir originalmente y otros que vas desbloqueando) con sus correspondientes habilidades especiales y bonus; una vez elegidos los personajes y la dificultad/modalidad de la campaña empiezas a jugar. Tienes 72 horas límite antes de que la inteligencia artificial que sujeta a tu corporación cual pilar maestro se quede sin batería y [strike]te vayas a tomar por culo [/strike] te den game over, en este tiempo tendrás que infiltrarte en diferentes bases y conseguir nuevos "gadgets" para tus agentes, armas y/o fondos para subvencionar la compra de estos en el mercado negro y hacer más eficientes a tus mercenarios; los niveles son generados proceduralmente, algo que está muy de moda ultimamente, así que las horas de jugabilidad aumentan de forma considerable.
Invisible, Inc. es un videojuego que me ha sorprendido muy gratamente, principalmente porque había oído opiniones de todo tipo y a gente diciendo que no era exactamente un juego de sigilo o que el elemento de sigilo era "opcional" y podías avanzar a fuerza de golpes, en plan berserker (bastante más difícil que intentar pasar desapercibido según mi experiencia, así que realmente no), mientras sí que es cierto que puedes eliminar a guardias o dejarlos fuera de combate, estas acciones a menudo tienen enormes costos a largo/corto plazo, alertando a guardias que oyen el disparo o ven el cadáver, reforzando la seguridad, restándote puntos de energía (necesarios para hackear cámaras de seguridad y cajas fuertes entre otros), etc. Ciertamente, el juego es bastante original en su premisa, se aparta de sus camaradas de género por su enfoque diferente y sus mecánicas, y eso conlleva ventajas y desventajas; pero desde luego, no es un juego que sea malo per se (para nada).

P.D.: El DLC te desbloquea desde el principio 4 nuevos personajes, aumentando desde el minuto 0 tu elenco de agentes, para que empieces directamente con algo de variedad y veas cual combo es el que mejor te funciona, también añade más aumentos y objetos para usar y algo más de dificultad en las misiones, para que no te sientas demasiado humillado cuando a los cuatro turnos acorralen a tus agentes y los dejen secos de un tiro.
¡Felices infiltraciones!

With all its different agents, augments, skills, and items there is a lot to explore. Tons of replay value, as every mission is procuderally generated so you never get the same map twice.
I'm also loving the alarm system. Each turn, the counter increases, so that every five turns the alarm level is raised and a new security feature is implemented. It forces you to be faster; you have to know when to leave and decide if looting that last safe over there is /really/ worth it.
If you don't like that though, you can just turn it off. There is a great amount of customization options so for anyone who is failing Experienced difficulty like me - don't worry, you can simply get rid of the thing that causes you to fail. Put more power stations into each level, make the maps smaller, disable the automatically increasing alarm, place more safes to loot. Whatever it is that frustrates you; you can get rid of it with one click.
10/10 would absolutely recommend if you like strategy games.

edit: No longer failing Experienced difficulty, I beat the game in Experienced, Expert, and Time Attack mode now, all of which once seemed impossible to even survive one level in. Which, nice, but also a reminder that you really do get better once you find what strategy works for you.

This game is a turn by turn strategy where a couple of spy try to infiltrate a complex, with a gameplay very close to the X-com games : you mouve a couple of guys, get info, stun enemies, then the computer play and you start again. If you like strategy and intersting micro-management, this game is for you.

I really like Invisible Ink, which is for me the elegent version of X-com two. There is less content, less graphics, less super-powers, but the ones that exists have intersting interaction, and therefore the gameplay is funnier than the one in the X-com series.
- first randomness is correctly managed. No unlucky shots, or bad luck when performing and action. Everything you do will work, but the enemy reaction and the level layout are randoms. This is definitively a good decision as it create the illusion that the enemy has a plan, and it makes exploration crucial.
- then, exploration is fun, as it's a poker game : the more you explore, the better decision you'll take and the more loot you will gain, but the more time you will loose. And time (in fact turns) are a precious ressource : as time passes, the enemy gets stronger and you'll have more gards, more enemy programs and harder hacking to handle.
- then the game is more readable : this is simple 2D, with simple cover, and simple actions. You don't have to try everything 10 times to understand how it works. Things just do what's written in the description, that's intuitive and cool. Difficulties comes from poker and interaction, not from hard to understand interface.
So if you like strategy, you'll like this game.
